commit_message:
Do not use privsep context when listing the namespaces in fullstack

The aim of this patch is to speed up the namespace listing and
avoid overloading the privsep daemon during the fullstack tests.

Change-Id: I95f024684c864aa75506b08a5f904a55267d09a8
Related-Bug: #1833717
Related-Bug: #1811515

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 21:14:59.000000000', 'message': 'Make NFS already mounted message debug level

When a share is already mounted there is currently a message logged at
info level stating this whenever mount is called. Mount is called for
every remote share when collecting stats, so this results in
unactionable and useless messages filling the log file once a minute by
default.

Since nothing needs to be done in this case, and it is not really useful
information to the administrator, this changes that logging to debug
level so it is only seen if enabling the verbosity where an admin would
want to see something like this.

Change-Id: If7dc84c50ca7c9bae878a72b330c6d5ef9a3bab1
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Make NFS already mounted message debug level

When a share is already mounted there is currently a message logged at
info level stating this whenever mount is called. Mount is called for
every remote share when collecting stats, so this results in
unactionable and useless messages filling the log file once a minute by
default.

Since nothing needs to be done in this case, and it is not really useful
information to the administrator, this changes that logging to debug
level so it is only seen if enabling the verbosity where an admin would
want to see something like this.

Change-Id: If7dc84c50ca7c9bae878a72b330c6d5ef9a3bab1
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

[{'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-27 12:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-08-27 12:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"reusing sqlite connections in different threads (such as from a pool) is safe, as long as no attempt is made to use them from multiple threads with no locking". do we have said locking?

Do we need to create a pool of connections, without only being used at the same time?'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-27 14:05:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-27 14:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> "reusing sqlite connections in different threads (such as from a pool) is safe, as long as no attempt is made to use them from multiple threads with no locking". do we have said locking?

My impression is that the user does not need to do any locking [1].

However, thinking it over, I came to a conclusion that, given that MT-induced bugs could be hard to debug going forward, and performance benefits of persistent connection is seemingly negligible, I've refactored the patch to just re-open the connection anew. That should make it more robust.

1. https://bugs.python.org/msg266955'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-27 14:08:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-27 18:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-08-28 01:24:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Sorry, my bad, reusing the connection is a comment I have left.
We use sqlite and run unit tests parallelly, I didn't expect there is concurrency issue."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-28 22:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-29 06:07:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> We use sqlite and run unit tests parallelly, I didn't expect there is concurrency issue.

It seems that threading happens when running under Flask as a server - perhaps it threads internally."}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-29 12:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-08-30 08:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-30 08:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-30 08:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-08-30 10:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-30 13:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2019-08-30 13:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> It occurs to me that this is likely the actual behavior of most BMCs....

This thought keeps coming to my mind as well... So I though that may be we should reshape sushy-tools emulator into some sort of Redfish agent framework for the vendors to base their stuff on.

The hope is that this would make the whole BMC thing more stable and uniform across vendors, also easier to work with.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-08-30 14:25:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> So I though that may be we should reshape sushy-tools emulator into some sort of Redfish agent framework for the vendors to base their stuff on

I think I've been pretty vocal about this already, but I'm strongly against extending the scope of ironic to cover this. Although a cool project in theory."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-27 12:35:47.000000000', 'message': 'Run sqlite in MT mode

When opening a sqlite connection, the `check_same_thread` flag
should be flipped to `False`. With the default (which is `True`),
sushy-toole emulator fails on `sqlite.connect()` being cautious
running in a perceived MT environment.

The current default probably dates back to ~2012 when sqlite library
had some issues with MT. It seems to be alright since then [1].

1. https://bugs.python.org/issue16509

Change-Id: Ic3e4618f44236c86e59c62bebfd817b40b5235aa

commit_message:
Do not reuse sqlite connection

Prior to this patch, `PersistentDict` has been reusing sqlite
connection for all subsequent calls. This proved to fail in
MT environments.

With this change, `PersistentDict` reopens sqlite connection from
each object and closes it down in hope to make it MT-safe.

Change-Id: Ic3e4618f44236c86e59c62bebfd817b40b5235aa

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-04 16:32:38.000000000', 'message': "Use run_immediately=True for _cleanup_running_deleted_instances

Currently, the periodic task that cleans up deleted instances that
are still running on the hypervisor fires approximately <interval>
seconds after nova-compute starts. This isn't ideal in cases where
an instance was deleted by a user while nova-compute was down,
because when nova-compute comes back up, there will be a delay
before the virt guests are cleaned up, their ports freed, etc.

This adds the run_immediately=True keyword argument to the periodic
task decorator to make the first run of the task occur shortly after
the task scheduler starts, so the cleanup will happen soon after
nova-compute is brought back up.

Change-Id: I6e086e0a2bffe12fd78373b3bc6215221dabc77e
"}]
commit_message:
Use run_immediately=True for _cleanup_running_deleted_instances

Currently, the periodic task that cleans up deleted instances that
are still running on the hypervisor fires approximately <interval>
seconds after nova-compute starts. This isn't ideal in cases where
an instance was deleted by a user while nova-compute was down,
because when nova-compute comes back up, there will be a delay
before the virt guests are cleaned up, their ports freed, etc.

This adds the run_immediately=True keyword argument to the periodic
task decorator to make the first run of the task occur shortly after
the task scheduler starts, so the cleanup will happen soon after
nova-compute is brought back up.

Change-Id: I6e086e0a2bffe12fd78373b3bc6215221dabc77e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 05:36:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix filter() usage for Py 3

The use of filter() within the codebase expected the output to be
an interator, but the filter function in Python 3 now returns a
lazy loading generator and resulted in stack traces.

This commit replaces the use of filter() (+ lambdas) with more
readable list comprehension to be compatible with Python 2 and 3.

Change-Id: I56af1dc1f6648ec334f901cb59893240b0125031
'}]
commit_message:
Fix filter() usage for Py 3

The use of filter() within the codebase expected the output to be
an interator, but the filter function in Python 3 now returns a
lazy loading generator and resulted in stack traces.

This commit replaces the use of filter() (+ lambdas) with more
readable list comprehension to be compatible with Python 2 and 3.

Change-Id: I56af1dc1f6648ec334f901cb59893240b0125031

Volume.Backup restore fixes

for the volume backup restoration name or id (or both) is required. Do
not force both to be set in v2.
- Add restore unit tests
- Add new properties in v3 and QP for v2 and v3
- Move test_stats that ended up in `block_store`. Heh?

Change-Id: Ie118afe0116ced3580e52941e69cbc57bea2f7f8

commit_message:
Re-propose stable device rescue for Train

While this is mostly the same from Newton a new Upgrade Impacts section
has been added specifically calling out how evacuations to older
computes will be blocked within the compute API by a new version check.

Previously-approved: Mitaka, Newton.
blueprint virt-rescue-stable-disk-devices
Change-Id: I845f1e552a7fafbafcdae8139f35a766716b7c68

[{'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-08 16:58:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-04-09 15:52:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)

I have my doubts around the 'legacy' policy and also suspect there will be some pushback on adding more stuff to the NUMA objects. I honestly don't see how we could do this with placement now or in the mid-term future though, so this (to me) is really the only viable path we have"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-04-09 16:05:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not really in a position to evaluate this completely, but reading through nothing set off alarm bells.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-09 16:16:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-09 16:25:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-04-09 21:09:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I too have some concern around adding this feature in the legacy way, but it's true the ability for affinity in placement is a long way off. And the changes described in this spec seem fairly minor, so maybe it's not so bad."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-10 16:22:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

HTH'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-04-16 13:53:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I definitely don't want to be building any more legacy filter-based numa scaffolding than we absolutely need, so I'm kinda looking at this as maybe something we could pare down to be less flexible while providing an incremental improvement on the road to doing this properly with placement..."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-04-16 13:56:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-16 15:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:29:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

I'll simplify the spec and not provide a specific UX, meaning that NUMA affinity will be 'preferred' by default with no way to either disable it or ask for 'required'."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-18 12:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-18 13:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-04-18 13:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-04-18 13:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I have a question about the weigher inline.
cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-05-01 20:53:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-30 18:41:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)

I'm not convinced we should invest in this, given how close we are to being able to model NUMA and affinity in placement, and given that it's not a complete solution. But I'll just abstain from voting in case others feel strongly that it's worth moving forward."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-05-31 06:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-04 12:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-04 12:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

Looks good overall. 

If we can foresee that both placement and nova can be changed over to NUMA modelling in placement with a similar effort than this spec. Then I would like to go with the generic placement based solution.

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-04 13:50:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(7 comments)

Questions inline. Agree this should drop the hard SLA use case since it's about soft affinity best effort."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-04 14:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-04 14:12:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Let's clean this up to avoid the confusion over the goal of the change (soft vs hard affinity)."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-06-11 15:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-06-11 15:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-11 19:14:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(4 comments)

A few more questions inline, specifically about the claim this time.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-11 19:16:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-11 19:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-06-17 15:15:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-17 15:36:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

A couple nits but otherwise I think this looks good. I like making it generic enough to track RP UUIDs instead of just gpus specifically.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-24 21:09:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The Placement spec for nested magic 1 [1] is approved and some pieces of the implementation are already complete [2] [3].

IMO we should be investing in implementing the remainder on the Placement side (same_subtree [4] and resourceless request groups [5] are the necessary pieces) and using them in Nova, rather than in what's described in this spec, which will immediately become tech debt and make it harder to do that.

For now I'll stick with my +0 as stated in PS6, but I'm very close to -1.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/specs/train/approved/2005575-nested-magic-1.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/placement-api-microversion-history.html#support-string-request-group-suffixes
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/665492/ (probably not directly relevant to NUMA modeling/affinity)
[4] https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/specs/train/approved/2005575-nested-magic-1.html#same-subtree
[5] https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/specs/train/approved/2005575-nested-magic-1.html#resourceless-request-groups"}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-07-03 16:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-07-03 16:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-03 22:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm going to take a stand on this for two reasons:

- Retrofitting Placement-modeled VGPUs to work "the old way" is a step in the wrong direction. It is important that we (Nova) send the message that we're serious about finally modeling NUMA in placement.
- The necessary work to enable the above is very close. The only feature that isn't already merged (same_subtree + resourceless request groups [1]) is very close to ready.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668376/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-09 22:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

same_subtree + resourceless [1] is merged and available as microversion 1.36.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668376/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 22:26:29.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This spec aims to describe how to provide NUMA affinity for vGPUs.

Change-Id: I048e213eac3c7713a8426c4373014a9f68e154ac
Describes: bp libvirt-vgpu-numa-affinity

Have you considered:

1. Would cinder also benefit from direct download?
2. Would other glance backends (e.g. swift, sheepdog, cinder, vmware) also benefit from direct download?

If the answer to either or both of these questions is yes, it might be worth a small separate library for this like os-vif and os-brick, but for glance backends.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-05-24 08:51:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > Thank you for taking the time to review this. I think the proposed
 > change is not currently implemented.

Apologies again for the confusion, it helps if I actually read and take in the use case section of specs. I've got some additional questions but overall this seems like a valid optimisation and as Matt has suggested an opportunity to share code between Nova and Cinder."}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-05-24 17:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> 1. Would cinder also benefit from direct download?
I'm not sure I understand this. Volumes typically are cloned/mounted directly in their backend, just like Lee pointed out is already happening, so I think there's nothing else to do here.

>2. Would other glance backends (e.g. swift, sheepdog, cinder, vmware) also benefit from direct download?
Swift - yes, that was the point of the pluggable download entrypoint earlier. This would be a covered use case.

Here is a link to previous attempt of the spec:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/572805/
And implementation:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/574301/

The comments then suggested that instead of the pluggable mechanism, it should be implemented specifically for RBD. The pluggable mechanism was also deprecated and was also removed in the past, I can't find a link to that now."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-05 00:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

I think this is something that makes sense to add to nova -- if we can detect that an image lives in ceph, we can leverage a direct download to make things more efficient. Some questions and comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-06-07 00:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-06-07 00:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Overall I think this looks good. The use case is clear and the approach general idea is clear. Just some questions inline about details.'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-07-25 12:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-07-25 12:27:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-07-25 22:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Directly download and upload images to RBD

In the setup where Ceph is used by Glance but Nova uses local storage
for instances, Nova will be able to pull Glance images stored in Ceph
directly from Ceph instead of streaming the payload over the Glance
HTTP API. Similarly, the upload of instance snapshots will occur
directly to Ceph and the snapshot will be registered in Glance with
a location URL pointing to Ceph, instead of by a payload upload over
HTTP API via Glance.

Change-Id: I3b5fcb161f79c55c573aafe5c58e40e21322c50e

Not approving because I don't have the background to understand whether we actually want to / should do this."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-26 15:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-26 20:45:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I think this is a big change that should not be taken lightly at all, especially based on what I perceive to be a whim from a single customer complaining that they didn't know about the host_status thing (what's listed in the alternatives section). Beyond my fears about this being a slippery slope, I'm definitely -1 on having multiple meanings of what UNKNOWN is - because we have the down cell partial results case today and then what you're proposing here which so far as I can tell is not saying we'd return partial results in that case as well (like the down cell case)."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-26 21:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-26 21:27:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)

> (6 comments)
 > 
 > I think this is a big change that should not be taken lightly at
 > all, especially based on what I perceive to be a whim from a single
 > customer complaining that they didn't know about the host_status
 > thing (what's listed in the alternatives section). Beyond my fears
 > about this being a slippery slope, I'm definitely -1 on having
 > multiple meanings of what UNKNOWN is - because we have the down
 > cell partial results case today and then what you're proposing here
 > which so far as I can tell is not saying we'd return partial
 > results in that case as well (like the down cell case).

This isn't  a whim that they don't about host_status. They know about it, but they find it problematic that server status says ACTIVE when we know it might not be, and that server status is not consistent with host_status. They are looking for some consistency between the two. I don't think that's unreasonable."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:11:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> This isn't  a whim that they don't about host_status. They know
 > about it, but they find it problematic that server status says
 > ACTIVE when we know it might not be, and that server status is not
 > consistent with host_status. They are looking for some consistency
 > between the two. I don't think that's unreasonable.

I think it's a misunderstanding about what we know. The case they have in their heads is "the compute node is down, which is why the host_status says it's down or unknown, which means the instance is probably offline." However, that's only one case, and I'd wager that in the grand scheme of things, it's low on the list of reasons why we determine the host down. If I had to guess, I'd expect "because we're applying patches and the service is down" would be the top reason, followed by "an upgrade is happening and all compute services in a region/cell are down", followed by "rabbit is overwhelmed."

If the concern is really just about harmonizing the two things for display, then surely a change to OSC/Horizon to consider the host_state key and alter, alert, or change the "status" we show to the user would be a big improvement right?

Actually exposing the UNKNOWN state to the user when the host appears down is throwing away information --mainly, what the state was before we lost contact with the host. If something big is happening, and I as a user need to come up with the most efficient way to get my stuff back up, I need to determine which instances are dead and rebuild/redeploy elsewhere. If I can list my instances and see which ones were ACTIVE as of the last report, I can quickly hit those and see if indeed they're down, or if if the host status is just warning that the service is stopped, but the instances are fine. I could potentially look at power_state, but I'd have to infer active-ness from that, I wouldn't know which instances might have been stuck in VERIFY_RESIZE, SNAPSHOTTING, MIGRATING, etc. And, if consistent states are important, wouldn't we want to short-circuit the power_state to NOSTATE as well?

I'm -2 on making the instance state go to some terminal state like SHUTOFF if the host does. I won't -2 a move to UNKNOWN (or something else implying we don't know what the state is), but I think it's the wrong move (for the API) to do that. I definitely sympathize with Matt's concern over UNKNOWN being confused with the "most of the instance is gone" vs. "the host is down", and I think I brought that up on the ML.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think there is two distinct things here:

- VM is down because host is down
- VM is un-manageable because service is down

It's pretty hard to tell the difference from both (from Nova's perspective) but it is possible that an instance is in "UNKNOWN" state but it is still up and running.

I really like the idea but I think maybe we can find another term like "UNMANAGABLE" or.. something along those lines.  The idea is that as a consumer, you understand that the VM is not necessarily down but it cannot have any operations done to it (..and also potentially down).

Also, something that comes to mind as an operator is will UNKNOWN be exposed to users only?  Can I do evacuates on an instance that is UNKNOWN?'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:37:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I think there is two distinct things here:
 > 
 > - VM is down because host is down
 > - VM is un-manageable because service is down
 > 
 > It's pretty hard to tell the difference from both (from Nova's
 > perspective) but it is possible that an instance is in "UNKNOWN"
 > state but it is still up and running.

Possible, and likely, if you assume my ordering of reasons why the host might be "down" to nova.

 > I really like the idea but I think maybe we can find another term
 > like "UNMANAGABLE" or.. something along those lines.  The idea is
 > that as a consumer, you understand that the VM is not necessarily
 > down but it cannot have any operations done to it (..and also
 > potentially down).
 
Is it important for this to be something that the API tells you vs. just OSC or Horizon? Because, again, this is information loss. I do like "unmanageable" much better than re-using "unknown" or one of the other states, if we must do this.

 > Also, something that comes to mind as an operator is will UNKNOWN
 > be exposed to users only?  Can I do evacuates on an instance that
 > is UNKNOWN?

Certainly we have to allow that, otherwise you can't do evacuate anymore. It has to be shown to users, according to the value proposition laid out here, otherwise there is no "benefit". Showing a different state to admins and users (if that's what you were implying) would not be reasonable, IMHO.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > This isn't  a whim that they don't about host_status. They know
 > > about it, but they find it problematic that server status says
 > > ACTIVE when we know it might not be, and that server status is
 > not
 > > consistent with host_status. They are looking for some
 > consistency
 > > between the two. I don't think that's unreasonable.
 > 
 > I think it's a misunderstanding about what we know. The case they
 > have in their heads is "the compute node is down, which is why the
 > host_status says it's down or unknown, which means the instance is
 > probably offline." However, that's only one case, and I'd wager
 > that in the grand scheme of things, it's low on the list of reasons
 > why we determine the host down. If I had to guess, I'd expect
 > "because we're applying patches and the service is down" would be
 > the top reason, followed by "an upgrade is happening and all
 > compute services in a region/cell are down", followed by "rabbit is
 > overwhelmed."

I agree with your wager here, that most of the time, an UNKNOWN host means some sort of maintenance is happening to the host or rabbit is on the fritz. But I think the maintenance cases are a good example of an UNKNOWN server status being helpful. If the compute host is undergoing maintenance, there's a chance my server might go down if the maintenance people reboot the compute host. And UNKNOWN gives me a hint not to be surprised if that happens. I realize patching a compute host may not involve a reboot though. So, I think your point is that most of the time, a host status of UNKNOWN will not mean the server is unusable.

 > If the concern is really just about harmonizing the two things for
 > display, then surely a change to OSC/Horizon to consider the
 > host_state key and alter, alert, or change the "status" we show to
 > the user would be a big improvement right?

That would be an improvement, yes, but that's not giving us any consistency from our own REST API. We're still in a situation where we show host status UNKNOWN and server status ACTIVE.

 > Actually exposing the UNKNOWN state to the user when the host
 > appears down is throwing away information --mainly, what the state
 > was before we lost contact with the host. If something big is
 > happening, and I as a user need to come up with the most efficient
 > way to get my stuff back up, I need to determine which instances
 > are dead and rebuild/redeploy elsewhere. If I can list my instances
 > and see which ones were ACTIVE as of the last report, I can quickly
 > hit those and see if indeed they're down, or if if the host status
 > is just warning that the service is stopped, but the instances are
 > fine. I could potentially look at power_state, but I'd have to
 > infer active-ness from that, I wouldn't know which instances might
 > have been stuck in VERIFY_RESIZE, SNAPSHOTTING, MIGRATING, etc.
 > And, if consistent states are important, wouldn't we want to
 > short-circuit the power_state to NOSTATE as well?

This is the point that gives me pause about my proposal. I can sympathize with the scenario of someone needing to know what was the last known state of the server in order to take recovery actions.

So... I must admit this point is making me think about other possibilities, like exposing host status UNKNOWN unconditionally regardless of policy. Today it defaults to admin-only and exposes all statuses including forced_down and maintenance, details the cloud operator may not want end users to see. But UNKNOWN would be safe to expose, I think. Thoughts?

 > I'm -2 on making the instance state go to some terminal state like
 > SHUTOFF if the host does. I won't -2 a move to UNKNOWN (or
 > something else implying we don't know what the state is), but I
 > think it's the wrong move (for the API) to do that. I definitely
 > sympathize with Matt's concern over UNKNOWN being confused with the
 > "most of the instance is gone" vs. "the host is down", and I think
 > I brought that up on the ML.

Understood. I wouldn't want to move the server status into any state other than UNKNOWN, because if we've lost comms with the compute host, we really don't know what the status is. And yes, you did mention concern for potential confusion over "partial server" vs "host unknown" on the ML. I don't have as much concern about that. To me, UNKNOWN is unknown, all bets are off, might be partial info, might be stale info, it's unknown. But perhaps I'm not foreseeing problems that would arise from that. I think the example you made was, someone wrote automation to handle UNKNOWN servers, making sure not to access fields that are not populated. In that scenario, I'd think it's OK if they did the same for other UNKNOWN servers that do have all fields populated that could be wrong/stale.

I have a lot of concern about the previous point you made though, about losing the last known status of the server if something happens with the comms between the API and the compute host.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> That would be an improvement, yes, but that's not giving us any
 > consistency from our own REST API. We're still in a situation where
 > we show host status UNKNOWN and server status ACTIVE.

Well, I think we disagree about what consistency means here, or what "good" means when it comes to consistency. I think that in over 50% of the cases where you would return UNKNOWN, we're implying or guessing that there's a problem when there isn't. If my health script monitors for ACTIVE, what (the eff) do a I do if the instance goes to UNKNOWN state? Today, I probably freak out and do something if the state changes to something I don't recognize or handle specifically, which means in the over-50% case, after this change, I would start destroying and rebuilding instances that are completely fine just because firefox needed updating on the host (hyperbole).

We can just throw up the "take me to the dealer" light any time there is a condition between "low tire" and "engine about to explode", or we can have multiple lights indicating the things we know. IMHO, the API should expose what we know in a sufficiently abstract way -- clients (users or software) should interpret that.

 > This is the point that gives me pause about my proposal. I can
 > sympathize with the scenario of someone needing to know what was
 > the last known state of the server in order to take recovery
 > actions.
 > 
 > So... I must admit this point is making me think about other
 > possibilities, like exposing host status UNKNOWN unconditionally
 > regardless of policy. Today it defaults to admin-only and exposes
 > all statuses including forced_down and maintenance, details the
 > cloud operator may not want end users to see. But UNKNOWN would be
 > safe to expose, I think. Thoughts?

I would expect some operators to want their users to be able to see this all the time. Internal corporate clouds, NFV infrastructure clouds, etc. I would expect public clouds to not want their users to ever see it, or never see that they have "forced down" a host. We added the "hidden" flag to the migration record specifically because big clouds wanted to be able to move instances around via live migration to account for maintenance without their users inferring what that may mean. They had been doing this all along, but when we added a migration record for live migrations, we needed a way to make it not visible to users, if needed.

So I guess my point is, host_status is already policy-controlled. If admins want their users to know, they can enable that for them. If they don't, then they don't, and exposing anything in the instance status about host-down-ness would be a violation of that.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

These two points explain my feelings well:

> We can just throw up the "take me to the dealer" light any time there is a condition between "low tire" and "engine about to explode", or we can have multiple lights indicating the things we know. IMHO, the API should expose what we know in a sufficiently abstract way -- clients (users or software) should interpret that.

^ is the slippery slope I'm afraid of if we just make this change and think there won't be big implications later, i.e. weird edge cases about needing to know more details about what UNKNOWN really means here and what sort of capabilities are available to a server that is in UNKNOWN status.

> So I guess my point is, host_status is already policy-controlled. If admins want their users to know, they can enable that for them. If they don't, then they don't, and exposing anything in the instance status about host-down-ness would be a violation of that.

And this was the original point I made in the mailing list - we already provide the information for an end user application to make decisions on what we give them (like Dan's Horizon/OSC example) assuming the cloud is configured to expose host_status to its users (mostly private dev/ops or NFV single tenant cloud). If we wanted to make that host_status exposure more granular based on the actual host_status, i.e. only show it if (1) the request passes a more fine-grained policy check and (2) the host_status=UNKNOWN because the service group API says it's not up, then that's a much more scoped and conservative approach I'd be more comfortable with.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:42:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If we wanted
 > to make that host_status exposure more granular based on the actual
 > host_status, i.e. only show it if (1) the request passes a more
 > fine-grained policy check and (2) the host_status=UNKNOWN because
 > the service group API says it's not up, then that's a much more
 > scoped and conservative approach I'd be more comfortable with.

Yeah. I'm totes on board with making it more granular. I'm too policy-stupid to know what the mechanics of that are, but...yes."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-27 00:01:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for all of the thoughtful feedback. I'll take some more time to digest all the comments. So far, I'm thinking a new, granular policy rule for 'show:host_status_unknown' would give the value I'm looking for here.

 > host_status, i.e. only show it if (1) the request passes a more
 > fine-grained policy check and (2) the host_status=UNKNOWN because
 > the service group API says it's not up, then that's a much more
 > scoped and conservative approach I'd be more comfortable with.

host_status UNKNOWN is only returned from get_instance_host_status if service_is_up is False:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e59cc3/nova/compute/api.py#L4851-L4863

So I think it would just be a simple fine-grained policy check plus if UNKNOWN, show UNKNOWN."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-27 14:02:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The policy check actually happens in the view builder code:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e59cc3/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L322

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e59cc3/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L378

But yeah you'd have something along the lines of:

1. high enough microversion?
2. can view host status always (the thing we have)
3. can view host status if unknown (avoid the queries if we're not going to show it anyway)
4. get the host status for the instance and based on #2 and #3, show or don't show the host_status in the server response"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-06-27 18:20:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> The policy check actually happens in the view builder code:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e59cc3/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L322
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6e59cc3/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L378
 > 
 > But yeah you'd have something along the lines of:
 > 
 > 1. high enough microversion?
 > 2. can view host status always (the thing we have)
 > 3. can view host status if unknown (avoid the queries if we're not
 > going to show it anyway)
 > 4. get the host status for the instance and based on #2 and #3,
 > show or don't show the host_status in the server response

That's actually what I was experimenting with earlier this week [0]. At that point, you have access to the context and the instance (it looks like), so you should be able to make a reasonable decision about who is making the request and what level of authorization they have (e.g., if they're a system administrator nova won't filter host_status, if they're not a system administrator you can filter accordingly.)

The oslo.policy and oslo.context libraries should have everything nova needs to make these decisions. It'll just require some coordination between the new policy check string and the views code to filter status properly.

[0] https://pasted.tech/pastes/d7363625b6f8b52d68b6ab9515f8e796cb989e66.raw"}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-07-02 09:40:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

After reading the debate in the spec I think we might conflate two pieces of information to be shown in a single field and that cause some of the confusion:

1) what is the state of the server

2) what we know about the state of the server.

What if we keep the status field ACTIVE (or whatever state is has) but we add a field that state if our knowledge about such status is up-to-date with the reality or not? Something like:

status: ACTIVE / SHUTOFF / ERROR / ...
status-information-reliability: CURRENT / STALE

Where CURRENT means that the compute service update is within the configured timeout and STALE means that the compute service update timed out.

Btw, there is already a possible (but unlikely) way to get status UNKNOWN from the API: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/cf76777b612a288ab17d637408a1e7476c8d6323/nova/api/openstack/common.py#L117

In general I'd like to get the information to the end user about the situation when the ACTIVE (or other) status of a server is might or might not be match with the reality. Hence my +1."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-07-02 16:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> What if we keep the status field ACTIVE (or whatever state is has)
 > but we add a field that state if our knowledge about such status is
 > up-to-date with the reality or not? Something like:
 > 
 > status: ACTIVE / SHUTOFF / ERROR / ...
 > status-information-reliability: CURRENT / STALE
 > 
 > Where CURRENT means that the compute service update is within the
 > configured timeout and STALE means that the compute service update
 > timed out.

I feel like we already have this, in the form of host-status :)

 > Btw, there is already a possible (but unlikely) way to get status
 > UNKNOWN from the API: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/cf76777b612a288ab17d637408a1e7476c8d6323/nova/api/openstack/common.py#L117

Right, so this use is to cover the case of DB corruption. IIRC, it was there to handle cases like when you upgraded to new code, but then rolled back without restoring a DB snapshot. If the newer code had introduced a new state/status then this makes sure we return something indicating the problem. It's pretty consistent with the other use of UNKNOWN, which is the cell-down case where we literally don't know the status of the instance. It's a good reason to *not* reuse UNKNOWN to also mean "well, we kinda know, but the host is down, so we're conflating the other two (very serious) cases of unknown with this one, but there may be no problem at all..." :)

 > In general I'd like to get the information to the end user about
 > the situation when the ACTIVE (or other) status of a server is
 > might or might not be match with the reality. Hence my +1.

If host-status indicates not-okay-ness, then the instance state is not consistent with reality. Maybe we just need to update the api docs about what impact those states have on what we know about the instance? We could also add to the docs about status to indicate that the value may be stale if host_status is "UNKNOWN" or "DOWN". If it's "UP" or "MAINTENANCE" then the instance status should be accurate.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-02 22:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-02 22:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

im more or less neutral on this by the way hence no + or - 1
i think having a unknon status is  resonably im just not sure non admins should see it.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-07-03 13:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > What if we keep the status field ACTIVE (or whatever state is
 > has)
 > > but we add a field that state if our knowledge about such status
 > is
 > > up-to-date with the reality or not? Something like:
 > >
 > > status: ACTIVE / SHUTOFF / ERROR / ...
 > > status-information-reliability: CURRENT / STALE
 > >
 > > Where CURRENT means that the compute service update is within the
 > > configured timeout and STALE means that the compute service
 > update
 > > timed out.
 > 
 > I feel like we already have this, in the form of host-status :)
 > 
 > > Btw, there is already a possible (but unlikely) way to get status
 > > UNKNOWN from the API: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/cf76777b612a288ab17d637408a1e7476c8d6323/nova/api/openstack/common.py#L117
 > 
 > Right, so this use is to cover the case of DB corruption. IIRC, it
 > was there to handle cases like when you upgraded to new code, but
 > then rolled back without restoring a DB snapshot. If the newer code
 > had introduced a new state/status then this makes sure we return
 > something indicating the problem. It's pretty consistent with the
 > other use of UNKNOWN, which is the cell-down case where we
 > literally don't know the status of the instance. It's a good reason
 > to *not* reuse UNKNOWN to also mean "well, we kinda know, but the
 > host is down, so we're conflating the other two (very serious)
 > cases of unknown with this one, but there may be no problem at
 > all..." :)
 > 
 > > In general I'd like to get the information to the end user about
 > > the situation when the ACTIVE (or other) status of a server is
 > > might or might not be match with the reality. Hence my +1.
 > 
 > If host-status indicates not-okay-ness, then the instance state is
 > not consistent with reality. Maybe we just need to update the api
 > docs about what impact those states have on what we know about the
 > instance? We could also add to the docs about status to indicate
 > that the value may be stale if host_status is "UNKNOWN" or "DOWN".
 > If it's "UP" or "MAINTENANCE" then the instance status should be
 > accurate.

I can accept a solution where the host-status is more exposed to the end user with a fair amount of documentation how you suggested'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-07-25 05:05:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-07-25 05:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Updated to describe the new policy rule proposal.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 22:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This change proposes a spec for the Train release, which is currently under spec freeze. If you still wish your spec to be considered for Train, you may restore it and follow the spec freeze exception process per [1]. Alternatively, you may propose your spec to the backlog per [2], or wait until the U release opens and propose it there.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/008060.html
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/readme.html#backlog-specifications'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-30 13:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The nova-specs repository has been populated for ussuri. You may restore and move this spec if needed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 22:36:15.000000000', 'message': 'Propose showing server status UNKNOWN when host status UNKNOWN

Spec for blueprint server-status-unknown-if-host-status-unknown

Change-Id: I7a5ba25b58ae2fd659aba14605cab3a5f8b30ad7
'}, {'created': '2019-06-19 05:55:19.000000000', 'message': 'Propose showing server status UNKNOWN when host status UNKNOWN

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 3031, 'name': 'Sam Morrison', 'email': 'sorrison@gmail.com', 'username': 'sorrison'}, {'_account_id': 4690, 'name': 'melanie witt', 'display_name': 'melwitt', 'email': 'melwittt@gmail.com', 'username': 'melwitt'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 7634, 'name': 'Takashi Natsume', 'email': 'takanattie@gmail.com', 'username': 'natsumet'}, {'_account_id': 10338, 'name': 'Daniel Speichert', 'email': 'daniel@speichert.pl', 'username': 'daniel'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-02-07 03:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-02-07 07:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

This spec should be submitted in the specs/train/approved directory.'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-02-07 21:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-02-09 00:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-02-10 22:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-03-12 22:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-03-12 22:45:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

FYI, there's a spec that has some similarities with this one, about implementing quota by resource class:

https://review.openstack.org/569011

This ^ is dependent on us moving to unified limits and oslo.limit in nova. It would be helpful if you could take a look through that spec and let us know if it solves the quota part of your use case. On the surface, it looks like your use case would be covered by the quota by resource class plan.

For the scheduling part, I tend to think we would not add flavor classes and instead you would decorate your flavors with traits."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-01 16:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Sam. We're resurrecting the 'backlog specs' process (see this thread [0]) and have noticed that there's a backlog spec by this same name [1] that was merged in 2015.

We need one of the following things to happen:

(a) That spec should be 'moved' from the backlog via the (newly refreshed) process described at [2]. You could do it in this commit, and the spec would (hopefully) show up as a "rename" from specs/backlog/approved.

or

(b) That spec should be 'abandoned' from the backlog via the (newly minted) process described at [3]. I've already proposed a patch for this at [4] as part of an overall effort to scrub the backlog. If you agree, you can +1 that patch. And then this one can stand on its own as is.

If the two specs are unrelated, (b) is more appropriate. If they are incarnations of the same idea, I would prefer (a) (and I'll abandon [4]).

Please let me know if you have any questions. Thanks!

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/thread.html#4290
[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/backlog/approved/flavor-class.html
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/00/648800/3/check/openstack-tox-docs/e601952/html/readme.html#backlog-specifications
[3] http://logs.openstack.org/00/648800/3/check/openstack-tox-docs/e601952/html/readme.html#abandoning-a-specification
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/649095/'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2019-05-03 17:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

As an operator, I would prefer a more generic solution as described in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/569011/. A static "flavor class" could quickly become not flexible enough. In terms of Horizon's representation, it could use something similar to metadata definition where "known" extra specs on flavors are used for grouping/display. In fact, the way flavors are going right now, it would make sense to make the whole flavor model configurable with a metadata definitions, instead of having primary (cpu, ram, disk, etc) and secondary (extra specs) citizens of the flavor model.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:49:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

This -2 is a "yes I have this very same use case, but I think we can do it differently now, at least to start with, but I am willing to change my mind" which amounts to "do not merge"

A flavor can request N items of a custom resource class, hypervisors will soon be able to report how much of that custom resource class they support, and with unified limits we can add a quota on that.

That can give you "pizza" slice scheduling you used to have with cells v1, like mushroom and meat feast, with two slice instances requesting two scheduling slots, etc.

I think that should get us what we always wanted from flavor classes, but I could be missing something.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:50:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For reference, this is where the latest quota info is currently proposed: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/602201'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Daniel I am doing what you propose (for quotas) here:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/602201'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 22:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This change proposes a spec for the Train release, which is currently under spec freeze. If you still wish your spec to be considered for Train, you may restore it and follow the spec freeze exception process per [1]. Alternatively, you may propose your spec to the backlog per [2], or wait until the U release opens and propose it there.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/008060.html
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/readme.html#backlog-specifications'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-30 13:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The nova-specs repository has been populated for ussuri. You may restore and move this spec if needed.'}]

[{'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-02-27 21:18:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2018-02-27 21:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

no service will work if using https as they dont have ssl certificates on the containers nor the services are configured to use tls on it.

Also many non core services non fully support ssl. I see this change as a partial implementation of internal tls, but as it is now, no service can work now'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-02-28 20:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-03-01 18:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi. The service works fine if you have a cert that is signed by a real CA. As We, GoDaddy, are a real CA, we can do that more easily than some, but also letsencrypt certs work fine. Either way, it works, and it works entirely via haproxy, so no internal services need to answer with TLS. We have this patch incorporated and are using it today to deploy our preliminary kolla-ansible deployed clouds right now.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-03-07 01:31:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

FYI, I'm aware that the backends for each service are still unencrypted. We'll be pushing through some follow-ups that make those use tls as well."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-03-23 07:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2018-03-26 19:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-06-08 05:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 18368, 'date': '2018-06-08 12:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Thanks Clint for your work on this feature - it has inspired the design which is being developed in other patches.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-27 21:18:09.000000000', 'message': "Allow disabling insecure API endpoints

In some cases the deployer may not want to allow non-TLS traffic to
their endpoints. Setting this to 'yes' will turn off the non-https
endpoints and flip internal vips to external ones so that all traffic
is sent to the secure endpoints.

Change-Id: I01cac037d027d3fc542c0046494dccd24f79affc
"}, {'created': '2018-02-28 20:28:09.000000000', 'message': 'Allow disabling insecure API endpoints

In some cases the deployer may not want to allow non-TLS traffic to
their endpoints. Setting this to 'yes' will turn off the non-https
endpoints and flip internal vips to external ones so that all traffic
is sent to the secure endpoints.

This includes adding "_external" versions of the keystone admin service
and the glance registry. These aren't intended to be "external", so
maybe we should change the name from "external" to just "tls".

Change-Id: I01cac037d027d3fc542c0046494dccd24f79affc

commit_message:
Allow disabling insecure API endpoints

In some cases the deployer may not want to allow non-TLS traffic to
their endpoints. Setting this to 'yes' will turn off the non-https
endpoints and flip internal vips to external ones so that all traffic
is sent to the secure endpoints.

Change-Id: I01cac037d027d3fc542c0046494dccd24f79affc

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-10 00:08:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add useful error log when _determine_version_cap raises DBNotAllowed

Change Icddbe4760eaff30e4e13c1e8d3d5d3f489dac3c4 was intended for the
API service to check all cells for the minimum nova-compute service
version when [upgrade_levels]/compute=auto.

That worked in the gate with devstack because we don't configure
nova-compute with access to the database and run nova-compute with
a separate nova-cpu.conf so even if nova-compute is on the same
host as the nova-api service, they aren't using the same config
file (nova-api runs with nova.conf which has access to the API DB
obviously).

The problem is when nova-compute is configured with
[upgrade_levels]/compute=auto and an [api_database]/connection,
there are flows that can try to hit the API database directly
because of the _determine_version_cap method. For example, the
_sync_power_states periodic task trying to stop an instance,
or even simple inter-compute communication over RPC like during
a resize.

This change simply catches the DBNotAllowed exception, logs a more
useful error message, and re-raises the exception. In addition,
the config help for the [api_database] group and "configuration"
option specifically are updated to mention they should not be set
on the nova-compute service.

Change-Id: Iac2911a7a305a9d14bc6dadb364998f3ecb9ce42
Related-Bug: #1807044
Closes-Bug: #1839360
(cherry picked from commit 7d7d58509d5e60ec19c6310931dc62eeff033595)
'}, {'created': '2019-08-12 19:12:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add useful error log when _determine_version_cap raises DBNotAllowed

a separate nova-cpu.conf so even if nova-compute is on the same
host as the nova-api service, they aren't using the same config
file (nova-api runs with nova.conf which has access to the API DB
obviously).

The problem is when nova-compute is configured with
[upgrade_levels]/compute=auto and an [api_database]/connection,
there are flows that can try to hit the API database directly
because of the _determine_version_cap method. For example, the
_sync_power_states periodic task trying to stop an instance,
or even simple inter-compute communication over RPC like during
a resize.

This change simply catches the DBNotAllowed exception, logs a more
useful error message, and re-raises the exception. In addition,
the config help for the [api_database] group and "configuration"
option specifically are updated to mention they should not be set
on the nova-compute service.

NOTE(mriedem): The test was modified to set the LAST_VERSION
global to None since change I48109d5e32a2e9635c240da1c77f7f6cc7e3c76d
is not in Stein.

Change-Id: Iac2911a7a305a9d14bc6dadb364998f3ecb9ce42
Related-Bug: #1807044
Closes-Bug: #1839360
(cherry picked from commit 7d7d58509d5e60ec19c6310931dc62eeff033595)
'}]
commit_message:
Add useful error log when _determine_version_cap raises DBNotAllowed

Change Icddbe4760eaff30e4e13c1e8d3d5d3f489dac3c4 was intended for the
API service to check all cells for the minimum nova-compute service
version when [upgrade_levels]/compute=auto.

That worked in the gate with devstack because we don't configure
nova-compute with access to the database and run nova-compute with
a separate nova-cpu.conf so even if nova-compute is on the same
host as the nova-api service, they aren't using the same config
file (nova-api runs with nova.conf which has access to the API DB
obviously).

The problem is when nova-compute is configured with
[upgrade_levels]/compute=auto and an [api_database]/connection,
there are flows that can try to hit the API database directly
because of the _determine_version_cap method. For example, the
_sync_power_states periodic task trying to stop an instance,
or even simple inter-compute communication over RPC like during
a resize.

This change simply catches the DBNotAllowed exception, logs a more
useful error message, and re-raises the exception. In addition,
the config help for the [api_database] group and "configuration"
option specifically are updated to mention they should not be set
on the nova-compute service.

NOTE(mriedem): The test was modified to set the LAST_VERSION
global to None since change I48109d5e32a2e9635c240da1c77f7f6cc7e3c76d
is not in Stein.

Change-Id: Iac2911a7a305a9d14bc6dadb364998f3ecb9ce42
Related-Bug: #1807044
Closes-Bug: #1839360
(cherry picked from commit 7d7d58509d5e60ec19c6310931dc62eeff033595)

commit_message:
Stop creating calico log directory

Disable log direction and rsyslog management of the calico-felix
service. This is logged to journal only now.

Depends-On: I3577ef4555cac3b05f27eb9589868034d2347889
Change-Id: I9ba5a13eb48b7a883d1ee04c69f4479b38195bce

commit_message:
Fix flavor profile API handling of None updates

The current flavor profile API does not properly handle
clearing/reseting values on update. Some mandatory fields would
return a database "cannot be Null" error. This patch raises the
proper invalid option execption.

Story: 2005374
Task: 33542

Change-Id: I5253c48871a8bb3bf91f82aa7791585cc4a6d529
(cherry picked from commit ab8a263674a918bf5a4f1c7ebf20594baad1d65a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-30 07:32:40.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor initialization of research context

The initialize function of RequestGroupSearchContext retrieved and
cached request-matching providers from database, but there could be
cases some data processing tasks are done before raising, which is
inefficient.

To reorder that data processing, this patch adds a new function,
from_reqgroup(), where we extract that data processings tasks into
smaller functions.

Change-Id: Ie76533c95e298725f8c7493d88552371d9b1cafb
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor initialization of research context

The initialize function of RequestGroupSearchContext retrieved and
cached request-matching providers from database, but there could be
cases some data processing tasks are done before raising, which is
inefficient.

To reorder that data processing, this patch adds a new function,
from_reqgroup(), where we extract that data processings tasks into
smaller functions.

Change-Id: Ie76533c95e298725f8c7493d88552371d9b1cafb

Neutron looks up which compute nodes are associated with each segment
with the placement API.

commit_message:
Add placement client for neutron

This is required if segmented provider networks are used in a cloud.
Neutron looks up which compute nodes are associated with each segment
with the placement API.

Change-Id: I7e8c0e3ef7aefd0574aa2a28560653005f2640d6
Related-Bug: 1818943
(cherry picked from commit 2cafbd1ae35b5fce3ba5c88c1c8d59937ca1eb46)

[{'created': '2019-08-19 14:40:39.000000000', 'message': 'Force "network_id" in "subnet" DB registers

The "subnet" OVO does not allow to have an empty (None) "network_id" but
the DB "subnet" table allows to have this parameter empty (NULL) in the
database. In order to avoid any problem like the one described in the
bug, this patch ensures the database "subnet" register does always have
a "network_id" value and if a "network" register is being deleted, all
related "subnet" registers are checked first.

Change-Id: Iad210f0585b4201fdb87187b44a9b42267b58db4
Closes-Bug: #1839658
'}, {'created': '2019-08-19 16:32:52.000000000', 'message': 'Force "network_id" in "subnet" DB registers

The "subnet" OVO does not allow to have an empty (None) "network_id" but
the DB "subnet" table allows to have this parameter empty (NULL) in the
database. In order to avoid any problem like the one described in the
bug, this patch ensures the database "subnet" register does always have
a "network_id" value and if a "network" register is being deleted, all
related "subnet" registers are checked first.

Change-Id: Iad210f0585b4201fdb87187b44a9b42267b58db4
Closes-Bug: #1839658
'}]
commit_message:
Force "network_id" in "subnet" DB registers

The "subnet" OVO does not allow to have an empty (None) "network_id" but
the DB "subnet" table allows to have this parameter empty (NULL) in the
database. In order to avoid any problem like the one described in the
bug, this patch ensures the database "subnet" register does always have
a "network_id" value and if a "network" register is being deleted, all
related "subnet" registers are checked first.

Change-Id: Iad210f0585b4201fdb87187b44a9b42267b58db4
Closes-Bug: #1839658

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-26 14:09:32.000000000', 'message': 'Fix L7 repository create methods

SQLAlchemy can get confused if the parent database objects are not
linked when creating new records using the repository.
For example, when creating an L7 policy, even if you specify the
listener_id, sqlalchemy will drop the ID from the final SQL INSERT
parameter.
This patch corrects the L7 policy and rule create methods to have
the required parent objects linked.

Story: 2006305
Task: 36021

Change-Id: I4380605bdb346eee824b2ce05fa25175c4cc3034
(cherry picked from commit 36afa82d0c9c61aa74ea922fcc769125afebd962)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix L7 repository create methods

SQLAlchemy can get confused if the parent database objects are not
linked when creating new records using the repository.
For example, when creating an L7 policy, even if you specify the
listener_id, sqlalchemy will drop the ID from the final SQL INSERT
parameter.
This patch corrects the L7 policy and rule create methods to have
the required parent objects linked.

Story: 2006305
Task: 36021

Change-Id: I4380605bdb346eee824b2ce05fa25175c4cc3034
(cherry picked from commit 36afa82d0c9c61aa74ea922fcc769125afebd962)

commit_message:
Change repository links usage in Dockerfile and build image

Used to be: git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-persister?h=stable/pike
Now : opendev.org/openstack/monasca-persister/src/branch/stable/pike

Since the way links to specific branches changed, usage of
those links has to be changed as well.
CONSTRAINTS_BRANCH variable was removed because CONSTRAINTS_FILE
contains link to the upper-requirements file with specified branch.

Story: 2005666
Task: 30971
Change-Id: If63cbc757386c18db4ec3d916ae058431aa92ea2

Define placement section when placement installed

Since we do not ship placement service for stein by default, we should

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-29 14:07:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add OVERCLOUD_SKIP_UPGRADE_SUPPORT_CHECK=1 in upgrade prepare.

Until the upgrade is considered supported in Stein we have disabled
the execution of the overcloud upgrade prepare command. To
be able to test the procedure, we need to pass the environment
variable OVERCLOUD_SKIP_UPGRADE_SUPPORT_CHECK=1.

Change-Id: I365d33accbbe87a08ddf4d02372e8d5465041ad9
'}]
commit_message:
Add OVERCLOUD_SKIP_UPGRADE_SUPPORT_CHECK=1 in upgrade prepare.

Until the upgrade is considered supported in Stein we have disabled
the execution of the overcloud upgrade prepare command. To
be able to test the procedure, we need to pass the environment
variable OVERCLOUD_SKIP_UPGRADE_SUPPORT_CHECK=1.

Change-Id: I365d33accbbe87a08ddf4d02372e8d5465041ad9

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I968b523f20edb5e9900c99bd919a9a5ede324eac
Story: #2005924
Task: #34221

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-30 17:43:46.000000000', 'message': "Add functional test for AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation + migrate

A bug was reported against Ocata where a non-admin user
creates a server and the user's project is isolated to a
set of hosts via the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter.

The admin, with a different project, cold migrates the server
and the filter rejects the request because before change
I195d389ac59574724a5e7202ba1a17d92c53a676 the cold migrate
task would re-generate the RequestSpec using the request context
which was from the admin, not the owner of the instance.

Even though this is not a problem past Ocata, we did not have
functional test coverage for this scenario so it is added here.

This will also be used to backport the fix to Ocata to show
the regression and fix in that branch.

Change-Id: I97559607fc720fb98c3543ff3dd6095281752cd4
Related-Bug: #1774205
Related-Bug: #1675607

commit_message:
Add functional test for AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation + migrate

A bug was reported against Ocata where a non-admin user
creates a server and the user's project is isolated to a
set of hosts via the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter.

The admin, with a different project, cold migrates the server
and the filter rejects the request because before change
I195d389ac59574724a5e7202ba1a17d92c53a676 the cold migrate
task would re-generate the RequestSpec using the request context
which was from the admin, not the owner of the instance.

Even though this is not a problem past Ocata, we did not have
functional test coverage for this scenario so it is added here.

This will also be used to backport the fix to Ocata to show
the regression and fix in that branch.

Change-Id: I97559607fc720fb98c3543ff3dd6095281752cd4
Related-Bug: #1774205
Related-Bug: #1675607

commit_message:
neutron-{vpnaas,fwaas}: Fix rootwrap filters install path

Neutron itself does install into /usr/share/neutron/rootwrap so use
the same path for the firewall/vpn services.

Change-Id: Ice5b0af87785ae19c7c869a0be458e4e58dfcee2

[{'created': '2019-08-22 12:27:43.000000000', 'message': 'Adds tls_priority parameter to nova::compute::libvirt

Override the compile time default TLS priority string. The
default is usually "NORMAL" unless overridden at build time.
Only set this if it is desired for libvirt to deviate from
the global default settings.

Related-Bug: #1840447
(cherry picked from commit 7f9c58f86cb4c7505fa04f0ad7e723ada09034ba)
'}]
commit_message:
Adds tls_priority parameter to nova::compute::libvirt

Override the compile time default TLS priority string. The
default is usually "NORMAL" unless overridden at build time.
Only set this if it is desired for libvirt to deviate from
the global default settings.

Change-Id: I221d48ba720e8ad820050fb5f735cd20d75f2f7a
Related-Bug: #1840447
(cherry picked from commit 7f9c58f86cb4c7505fa04f0ad7e723ada09034ba)

commit_message:
cinder: cleanup spec file

- cleanup service files
  * add Group, PrivateTmp and WorkingDirectory
  * move ExecPreStart to the correct file section
- Remove unneeded (for python3) enum34 dependency
- Package missing resource_filter.json file
- fix ownership of /var/lib/cinder

Change-Id: Iaa9b46d5119dada80d3bb370c637a2641dfde529

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-29 14:00:04.000000000', 'message': "Work around the request router's limitation

... of not being able to fully process member actions for the same
resource coming from multiple api-defs.

In the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def as it was first merged [1]
some router member actions (PUT add/remove_extraroutes) were defined
in one api-def (extraroute_atomic.py), while others
(PUT add/remove_router_interface) were defined in another (l3.py).

This (in the subsequent neutron implementation change [2]) broke
functional test:

neutron.tests.functional.pecan_wsgi.test_controllers.\
TestRouterController.test_unsupported_method_member_action

This test sent POST/GET /v2.0/routers/router-id/add_router_interface,
and expected response 405 Method Not Allowed. Due to the split
definition it actually received 404 Not Found. In the meanwhile all
four PUT member actions were working properly.

At the moment I don't see a better fix than to move all member actions
to l3.py and turn extraroute_atomic.py into a shim extension.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/670849
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670851/6

Change-Id: I95927d61a3590ea3495bc2716c1fa5fd4feb2948
Partial-Bug: #1826396 (rfe)
Related-Change: https://review.opendev.org/655680 (spec)
"}, {'created': '2019-08-29 15:09:58.000000000', 'message': "Introduce new member actions additively

In the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def as it was first merged [1]
some router member actions (PUT add/remove_extraroutes) were defined
in one api-def (extraroute_atomic.py), while others
(PUT add/remove_router_interface) were defined in another (l3.py).

This (in the subsequent neutron implementation change [2]) broke
functional test:

neutron.tests.functional.pecan_wsgi.test_controllers.\
TestRouterController.test_unsupported_method_member_action

This test sent POST/GET /v2.0/routers/router-id/add_router_interface,
and expected response 405 Method Not Allowed. Due to the split
definition it actually received 404 Not Found. In the meanwhile all
four PUT member actions were working properly.

This change sets the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def's ACTION_MAP to contain
the member actions of both the 'router' and the 'extraroute-atomic'
extensions' member actions in order to get all four member actions
properly defined.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/670849
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670851/6

Change-Id: I95927d61a3590ea3495bc2716c1fa5fd4feb2948
Partial-Bug: #1826396 (rfe)
Related-Change: https://review.opendev.org/655680 (spec)
"}, {'created': '2019-08-30 00:27:43.000000000', 'message': "Introduce new member actions additively

In the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def as it was first merged [1]
some router member actions (PUT add/remove_extraroutes) were defined
in one api-def (extraroute_atomic.py), while others
(PUT add/remove_router_interface) were defined in another (l3.py).

This (in the subsequent neutron implementation change [2]) broke
functional test:

neutron.tests.functional.pecan_wsgi.test_controllers.\
TestRouterController.test_unsupported_method_member_action

This test sent POST/GET /v2.0/routers/router-id/add_router_interface,
and expected response 405 Method Not Allowed. Due to the split
definition it actually received 404 Not Found. In the meanwhile all
four PUT member actions were working properly.

This change sets the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def's ACTION_MAP to contain
the member actions of both the 'router' and the 'extraroute-atomic'
extensions' member actions in order to get all four member actions
properly defined.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/670849
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670851/6

Change-Id: I95927d61a3590ea3495bc2716c1fa5fd4feb2948
Partial-Bug: #1826396 (rfe)
Related-Change: https://review.opendev.org/655680 (spec)
"}]
commit_message:
Introduce new member actions additively

In the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def as it was first merged [1]
some router member actions (PUT add/remove_extraroutes) were defined
in one api-def (extraroute_atomic.py), while others
(PUT add/remove_router_interface) were defined in another (l3.py).

This (in the subsequent neutron implementation change [2]) broke
functional test:

neutron.tests.functional.pecan_wsgi.test_controllers.\
TestRouterController.test_unsupported_method_member_action

This test sent POST/GET /v2.0/routers/router-id/add_router_interface,
and expected response 405 Method Not Allowed. Due to the split
definition it actually received 404 Not Found. In the meanwhile all
four PUT member actions were working properly.

This change sets the 'extraroute-atomic' api-def's ACTION_MAP to contain
the member actions of both the 'router' and the 'extraroute-atomic'
extensions' member actions in order to get all four member actions
properly defined.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/670849
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670851/6

Change-Id: I95927d61a3590ea3495bc2716c1fa5fd4feb2948
Partial-Bug: #1826396 (rfe)
Related-Change: https://review.opendev.org/655680 (spec)

commit_message:
Allow distribution of non-autogenerated certs

This patch changes the conditional run of the certs generation from
being dependent on the value of generate_certs to whether there are
actual certs present.

Note: this is a semantic backport of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672529/

Change-Id: I8088a0a42094b2d038ba29779535a05195138747
Related-Bug: #1838039

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-27 17:38:16.000000000', 'message': "Only generate Octavia certs on stack create

We are regenerating octavia certs whenever an overcloud is updated,
breaking any deployments using the auto-generated certs. Certificate
updates after the initial deployment require special handling and
shouldn't be performed by stack updates/upgrades at this time.

Note: depends on changed because the dependent patch was a semantic
backport.

Depends-On: I8088a0a42094b2d038ba29779535a05195138747
Closes-Bug: #1838039
Change-Id: I05f69df627e5637fdb254285cb3ad6d3d8328f90
(cherry picked from commit b61156785517f767a9ad0ee1613588f6b049fc8c)
"}]
commit_message:
Only generate Octavia certs on stack create

We are regenerating octavia certs whenever an overcloud is updated,
breaking any deployments using the auto-generated certs. Certificate
updates after the initial deployment require special handling and
shouldn't be performed by stack updates/upgrades at this time.

Note: depends on changed because the dependent patch was a semantic
backport.

Depends-On: I8088a0a42094b2d038ba29779535a05195138747
Closes-Bug: #1838039
Change-Id: I05f69df627e5637fdb254285cb3ad6d3d8328f90
(cherry picked from commit b61156785517f767a9ad0ee1613588f6b049fc8c)

commit_message:
Rework statistics reporting

- Add support for reporting statistics to InfluxDB
- Move stats configuration under 'metrics' section of the yaml file
- fix metric name build when url contains project id
- report timing in milliseconds
- add initial docs for metrics reporting
- fix metric names in some weird cases
- allow individual proxy to override metrics naming logic

Change-Id: I76d2d78dc2f4c8cecbf89b8cc101c2bb1dec1a2b

commit_message:
Add support for building pdf documentation

This patch updates tox.ini to build the pdf version of
cinderclient documentation.

run tox -epdf-docs

Change-Id: If1f43e593db6ff6740b8a88b517c4505e39a3edd

commit_message:
neutron: Create core plugin link and missing dirs

We use /etc/neutron/plugin.ini in the .service files but the file is
not there. So link it to out default plugin which is ml2.

Also create the default dirs under /var for neutron. Those are needed
to start neutron-server.

Change-Id: I05dd7bd23de41464b520713066d5ecd2e32785b6

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
