revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-27 18:52:45.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for IBM SVC

When initializing IBM SVC with the memory persistence we get an exception:

  return IMPL.volume_get_all_by_host(context, host, filters=filters)
  AttributeError: 'DB' object has no attribute 'volume_get_all_by_host'

The issue is caused by the SVC driver accessing the database directly,
which is not considered good practice in Cinder nowadays.

The problem with drivers using the DB directly is that cinderlib doesn't
require a DB, it can work storing everything in memory. To facilitate
storage of the resources' metadata cinderlib has its own persistence
plugin mechanism, and has some ad-hoc "workarounds" in the DB class for
drivers that access the DB directly.

The IBM driver has the following DB dependencies:

- volume_get_all_by_host when using objects.VolumeList.get_all_by_host

- volume_type_get when using objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_type_get_by_name when using
  objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_get directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.Volume.get_by_id

- _group_type_get_full directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.GroupType.get_by_id

In cinderlib we don't currently support groups or consistency groups, so
we don't need to implement `_group_type_get_full` and we have already
implemented workaround for methods `volume_get` and `volume_type_get`,
so this patch implements the remaining 2 methods volume_get_all_by_host
and volume_type_get_by_name in the DB class.

Closes-Bug: #1821898
Change-Id: I94b4864c5823976f4a9cac2e40943b74aca4066e
'}, {'created': '2019-03-28 14:25:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for IBM SVC

drivers that access the DB directly.

- volume_type_get when using objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_type_get_by_name when using
  objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_get directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.Volume.get_by_id

- _group_type_get_full directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.GroupType.get_by_id

- volume_admin_metadata_get direct call

- volume_admin_metadata_update direct call

- volume_admin_metadata_delete direct call

In cinderlib we don't currently support groups or consistency groups, so
we don't need to implement `_group_type_get_full` and we have already

so this patch implements the remaining 5 methods volume_get_all_by_host,
volume_type_get_by_name, volume_admin_metadata_get,
volume_admin_metadata_update, and volume_admin_metadata_delete in the DB
class.

Closes-Bug: #1821898
Change-Id: I94b4864c5823976f4a9cac2e40943b74aca4066e

commit_message:
Add support for IBM SVC

When initializing IBM SVC with the memory persistence we get an exception:

  return IMPL.volume_get_all_by_host(context, host, filters=filters)
  AttributeError: 'DB' object has no attribute 'volume_get_all_by_host'

The issue is caused by the SVC driver accessing the database directly,
which is not considered good practice in Cinder nowadays.

The problem with drivers using the DB directly is that cinderlib doesn't
require a DB, it can work storing everything in memory. To facilitate
storage of the resources' metadata cinderlib has its own persistence
plugin mechanism, and has some ad-hoc "workarounds" in the DB class for
drivers that access the DB directly.

The IBM driver has the following DB dependencies:

- volume_get_all_by_host when using objects.VolumeList.get_all_by_host

- volume_type_get when using objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_type_get_by_name when using
  objects.VolumeType.get_by_name_or_id

- volume_get directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.Volume.get_by_id

- _group_type_get_full directly called by get_by_id when using
  objects.GroupType.get_by_id

- volume_admin_metadata_get direct call

- volume_admin_metadata_update direct call

- volume_admin_metadata_delete direct call

In cinderlib we don't currently support groups or consistency groups, so
we don't need to implement `_group_type_get_full` and we have already
implemented workaround for methods `volume_get` and `volume_type_get`,
so this patch implements the remaining 5 methods volume_get_all_by_host,
volume_type_get_by_name, volume_admin_metadata_get,
volume_admin_metadata_update, and volume_admin_metadata_delete in the DB
class.

Closes-Bug: #1821898
Change-Id: I94b4864c5823976f4a9cac2e40943b74aca4066e

commit_message:
Remove openSUSE 42.3 job

openSUSE 42.3 is dead, remove the job, we test with openSUSE 15 now (as
on master). This allows to remove the nodes from CI.

This also removes non voting jobs from gates.

[{'created': '2019-08-28 13:08:08.000000000', 'message': 'neutron: Fix alias for openstack-neutron-server.service

We want the alias to be available for "systemctl enable" which does
not work when creating it in the [Install] section of the unit file.
Instead we create the alias now by adding the "openstack-neutron"
symlink to the package. As outlined in the systemd.unit(5) man page.

Change-Id: Ifb5d567cc1b7857f0a602018fcc11fcd52e92135
'}]
commit_message:
neutron: Fix alias for openstack-neutron-server.service

We want the alias to be available for "systemctl enable" which does
not work when creating it in the [Install] section of the unit file.
Instead we create the alias now by adding the "openstack-neutron"
symlink to the package. As outlined in the systemd.unit(5) man page.

Change-Id: Ifb5d567cc1b7857f0a602018fcc11fcd52e92135

[{'created': '2019-05-24 20:02:57.000000000', 'message': "Adding references for OctaviaDriverAgent images

Adds variables for setting up OctaviaDriverAgent. The driver agent
doesn't require its own container image yet.

commit_message:
Adding references for OctaviaDriverAgent images

Adds variables for setting up OctaviaDriverAgent. The driver agent
doesn't require its own container image yet.

Change-Id: I071783d7a7e0aacfccb25df8b18b8782e3bf3a05

commit_message:
Fix for k8s client annotation

This commit changes the behaviour of k8s client
while annotating. K8s client should not throw exceptions
if there are conflicts in data and resourceVersion
is different. It should resolve conflicts properly
and try to patch annotations once again changing
resourceVersion.

If data is the same in process of annotating, then
k8s client should not annotate many times.

Change-Id: I7d981b59ecdae7fe434fe580f2f342cc4621198e
Signed-off-by: Danil Golov <d.golov@samsung.com>

commit_message:
WIP Ensure svc without selectors are processed

Kuryr will skip the svc without endpoints so it does need to
skip svc without selectors. This way if endpoints are added
this svc will also be handled by kuryr

Change-Id: I93114b9b9132c0b078f3402ebe64c60518ec3dc1

commit_message:
Identify Cinder as the Block Storage Service

According to openstack/governance/projects.yaml, Cinder is the
OpenStack Block Storage service.  This patch changes the specs
index page to reflect this.

Partial-bug: #1841645

[{'created': '2019-07-23 08:26:38.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Report PCPU to placement

This patch does following things:
1. 'NUMACell' and 'InstanceNUMACell' object ready to accept 'PCPU'.
2. Added below conf option under 'compute' section:
    [compute]
    cpu_dedicated_set
3. Parse new config option CONF.compute.cpu_dedicated_set
   at libvirt driver side.
4. Populate the 'pcpuset' field of NUMACell object.
5. Report PCPU inventory to placement.

Partially Implements: blueprint cpu-resources
Change-Id: I1f10d09643d0d15d76b167b817183b989f52625d
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Report PCPU to placement

This patch does following things:
1. 'NUMACell' and 'InstanceNUMACell' object ready to accept 'PCPU'.
2. Added below conf option under 'compute' section:
    [compute]
    cpu_dedicated_set
3. Parse new config option CONF.compute.cpu_dedicated_set
   at libvirt driver side.
4. Populate the 'pcpuset' field of NUMACell object.
5. Report PCPU inventory to placement.

Partially Implements: blueprint cpu-resources
Change-Id: I1f10d09643d0d15d76b167b817183b989f52625d

commit_message:
WIP: Add scheduler request filter to alias cpu_policy

Added scheduler request filter to alias ``hw:cpu_policy``
set in flavor extra spec or image properties to
``resources=(V|P)CPU:${flavor.vcpus}`` and
``hw:cpu_thread_policy``  to
``trait:HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING=required|isolate``.

Partially Implements: blueprint cpu-resources

Change-Id: Ia764ee81abc3743276f40505f3a1df151ba5085d

commit_message:
WIP Upgrade patch to handle PCPU resource

Added upgrade code using reshape to report PCPU instead of VCPU in
case the host is configured to use pinned CPUs.

This patch does following things:

1. Handled all the configuration related errors.
2. Enable scheduler pre-filter 'alias_flavor_extra_specs'.
3. Any existing compute node running guests which uses dedicated CPUs
   is upgraded to Train release, it will update allocation records of
   existing guest from VCPU to PCPU using the reshape functionality.

Implements: blueprint cpu-resources
Change-Id: Ie272a11cb4f069320e6f7bfeb5a3bc25333eeff0

commit_message:
Revert "Handle defined containers that are stopped."

It is causing some containers (memcached) to be re-created at
every run, with the unique name. We need to rework the code
as well as it's breaking pacemaker-managed containers.
This reverts commit 85fb2ed4d3f7e42840842f2bdec617e33d6ba4ef.

Change-Id: I22d3eb35dced8178fe6beb0c76c855746efdf94d

[{'created': '2019-08-27 13:07:10.000000000', 'message': "The best effort pre-upgrade online data migrations were an attempt to
mitigate possible user errors if users forget to run the online data
migrations explicitly during the previous upgrade. However, they ended
up causing more problems than good:

* If user follows docs, they are unnecessary.

* If the containers for the services aren't running, they will get
  silently ignored already. This was done to facilitate re-runs of
  failed upgrade steps and prevent false failures. If the upgrade
  includes an operating system change, the pre-upgrade migrations will
  simply not run.

* However, if the containers for the services are running but the
  database is not running or is not functional for some reason, the
  migration will be attempted and the upgrade will get stuck. This
  leads to confusing errors not really related to the root cause of
  the problem, and non-straightforward breakages where the fix might
  otherwise be just to re-run the upgrade.

For the above reasons this commit removes the pre-upgrade just-in-case
online data migrations. We should be running them only as documented
in the upgrade workflow.

Change-Id: I5d3cc863f138d4f1a915e8a2060dd9ed1d577f37
Closes-Bug: #1841590
"}, {'created': '2019-08-27 13:08:34.000000000', 'message': "Remove pre-upgrade best-effort online data migrations

  simply not run.

* However, if the containers for the services are running but the
  database is not running or is not functional for some reason, the
  migration will be attempted and the upgrade will get stuck. This
  leads to confusing errors not really related to the root cause of
  the problem, and non-straightforward breakages where the fix might
  otherwise be just to re-run the upgrade.

For the above reasons this commit removes the pre-upgrade just-in-case
online data migrations. We should be running them only as documented
in the upgrade workflow.

Change-Id: I5d3cc863f138d4f1a915e8a2060dd9ed1d577f37
Closes-Bug: #1841590
"}]
commit_message:
Remove pre-upgrade best-effort online data migrations

The best effort pre-upgrade online data migrations were an attempt to
mitigate possible user errors if users forget to run the online data
migrations explicitly during the previous upgrade. However, they ended
up causing more problems than good:

* If user follows docs, they are unnecessary.

* If the containers for the services aren't running, they will get
  silently ignored already. This was done to facilitate re-runs of
  failed upgrade steps and prevent false failures. If the upgrade
  includes an operating system change, the pre-upgrade migrations will
  simply not run.

* However, if the containers for the services are running but the
  database is not running or is not functional for some reason, the
  migration will be attempted and the upgrade will get stuck. This
  leads to confusing errors not really related to the root cause of
  the problem, and non-straightforward breakages where the fix might
  otherwise be just to re-run the upgrade.

For the above reasons this commit removes the pre-upgrade just-in-case
online data migrations. We should be running them only as documented
in the upgrade workflow.

Change-Id: I5d3cc863f138d4f1a915e8a2060dd9ed1d577f37
Closes-Bug: #1841590

commit_message:
zuul: add openstack/magnum to opendev

vexxhost/kue is a library that would like to make changes against
checked-out versions of openstack/magnum in gate (enabling us
to use things like Depends-On).

This change adds nothing but the project in order to allow us to
be able to do Depends-On.

Change-Id: I0c1abcd212c016bf15a18cb6f5c2554256fdb502

commit_message:
Add [elections] ML subject tag

The technical election officials use an [elections] subject tag on
all election-related communications to the openstack-discuss and
openstack-announce mailing lists, so record that in the open
community document along with the other recommended tags.

Change-Id: I2881ca7c432ad85d4b3d535b02086be6e83412bc

commit_message:
Add encoding to local_settings.py

In order to allow usage of non-latin symbols inside local_settings.py
magic comment is required according to PEP263[1]

While this can be overriden on master with config_template (since [2]),
this might be easily backported to earlier releases.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0263/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672170/

Change-Id: I9b07cf4a1ffdffab752f59e1510796c29a259b45
(cherry picked from commit 7bb294b92a61ea1bebcdce1943f48ffaf5c1cdee)

subject: Added some more output in logs in case of failure for "execute"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 9796, 'name': 'ChangBo Guo', 'email': 'glongwave@gmail.com', 'username': 'gcb'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26828, 'name': 'cjeanneret - deactivated', 'email': 'cedric.jeanneret@camptocamp.com', 'username': 'Tengu'}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-09 09:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-09 10:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2017-11-13 03:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-13 06:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2017-11-15 09:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-15 09:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-12-09 17:09:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

It's not always appropriate to log the output of a command that fails. Sometimes the status code is enough to have the application take a different action, and it's not actually an "error" that the deployer needs to deal with. Because we can't know when to log and when not, it's better to have the application log the output.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-12-11 05:31:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hello Doug, any case when the command output is not appropriate to log? In the case I try to squash, the command fails for the nova instance migration, and I don't have any clue of what's making it crash :/. If you have a better idea/pointer, please lemme know. Having output logs will definitively help me squashing my issue."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-12-11 15:59:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Hello Doug, any case when the command output is not appropriate to
 > log? In the case I try to squash, the command fails for the nova
 > instance migration, and I don't have any clue of what's making it
 > crash :/. If you have a better idea/pointer, please lemme know.
 > Having output logs will definitively help me squashing my issue.

An application might run an external command to test a condition (for example, is there a network interface on a specific subnet or is there enough space on a volume). Those commands are just probing for information, and the application will take different action based on the outcome (creating the interface or writing to a different volume). The output and error code do not need to be logged for those commands."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-12-11 16:00:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Hello Doug, any case when the command output is not appropriate to
 > log? In the case I try to squash, the command fails for the nova
 > instance migration, and I don't have any clue of what's making it
 > crash :/. If you have a better idea/pointer, please lemme know.
 > Having output logs will definitively help me squashing my issue.

My recommendation is to add log information to nova where the migration is being managed."}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-12-13 08:13:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Hello Doug, any case when the command output is not appropriate
 > to
 > > log? In the case I try to squash, the command fails for the nova
 > > instance migration, and I don't have any clue of what's making it
 > > crash :/. If you have a better idea/pointer, please lemme know.
 > > Having output logs will definitively help me squashing my issue.
 > 
 > My recommendation is to add log information to nova where the
 > migration is being managed.

hmm ok, but the command is called with this processutils method. I'd rather output as close as possible from the "source". We might add a new param, default to false, that allows to log the output in any conditions. I must confess, I don't really understand the conditional output a few lines bellow the one I added - maybe that's the root of my issue. I need to work a bit more on that commit, and poke in the nova code. Thanks for your inputs!'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2019-08-28 13:23:37.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

As I understand, consensus is that this should not be done in library, and author's account has bee deactivated since posting this change."}]

commit_message:
Added some more output in logs in case of failure for "execute"

If a command fails, it might be good to output the reason it failed, not
only the exit code.

Change-Id: Iaf023f0e86b2baca64cc60c853b7f726ad77fa0e
Closes-Bug: 1731185

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-12 16:45:28.000000000', 'message': 'Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: I798072e948d70bbc7b7e56d77229cf8d456fdcca
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

Change-Id: I798072e948d70bbc7b7e56d77229cf8d456fdcca
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Out-of-band `erase_devices` clean step for Proliant Servers

This commit adds new management interface `ilo5` to support an
out-of-band clean step for sanitize disk erase on ilo5 based
Proliant Servers.

Change-Id: I7b9fc6add6f6a616bdee4d94cb577e7a27a794e5
Story: #2006394
Task: #36269

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 12:11:47.000000000', 'message': 'functional: Fix reading from process pipes

Processes like ovn-northd and ovsdb-servers were not spawned as daemons.
That means processes were writing to stdout and stderr but the code has
actually never read anything. It caused processes to hang after a while
once the buffers got full.

This patch makes processes being spawned as daemons - see manpages for
more information about --detach paramter. Daemon spawns another child
process and its pid is written to its pidfile. Such pidfile is used when
there a need to deal with the process.

Closes-bug: #1837373

Change-Id: I63074fad823362ec6e8a2cad796e258ca200ad3a
'}, {'created': '2019-08-05 08:01:18.000000000', 'message': 'functional: Fix reading from process pipes

Processes like ovn-northd and ovsdb-servers were not spawned as daemons.
That means processes were writing to stdout and stderr but the code has
actually never read anything. It caused processes to hang after a while
once the buffers got full.

This patch makes processes being spawned as daemons - see manpages for
more information about --detach paramter. Daemon spawns another child
process and its pid is written to its pidfile. Such pidfile is used when
there a need to deal with the process.

Closes-bug: #1837373

Change-Id: I63074fad823362ec6e8a2cad796e258ca200ad3a
'}]
commit_message:
functional: Fix reading from process pipes

Processes like ovn-northd and ovsdb-servers were not spawned as daemons.
That means processes were writing to stdout and stderr but the code has
actually never read anything. It caused processes to hang after a while
once the buffers got full.

This patch makes processes being spawned as daemons - see manpages for
more information about --detach paramter. Daemon spawns another child
process and its pid is written to its pidfile. Such pidfile is used when
there a need to deal with the process.

Closes-bug: #1837373

Change-Id: I63074fad823362ec6e8a2cad796e258ca200ad3a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 15:19:38.000000000', 'message': 'Rescan after making partition changes

Long story short, we need to rescan after making
partition changes.

Without forcing a filesystem sync and rescan operation,
we rely upon lazy write-out from buffers to the block
device when operating with a ramdisk.

This is because ramfs does NOT actually operate with fsync
where as GNU parted utilizes fsync on the device in an
attempt to force the write to disk to occur. This is fine
if your booted with devfs, or say even a physical block
device that backs /dev, just not ramfs.

Change-Id: I66481d5f3c17a489f7bdf0af82e31b9107605968
Story: 2006423
Task: 36316
(cherry picked from commit 2a83c0add09abee2c12bc76658a66e253f236f95)

commit_message:
Rescan after making partition changes

Long story short, we need to rescan after making
partition changes.

Without forcing a filesystem sync and rescan operation,
we rely upon lazy write-out from buffers to the block
device when operating with a ramdisk.

This is because ramfs does NOT actually operate with fsync
where as GNU parted utilizes fsync on the device in an
attempt to force the write to disk to occur. This is fine
if your booted with devfs, or say even a physical block
device that backs /dev, just not ramfs.

Change-Id: I66481d5f3c17a489f7bdf0af82e31b9107605968
Story: 2006423
Task: 36316
(cherry picked from commit 2a83c0add09abee2c12bc76658a66e253f236f95)

commit_message:

Current filter rule gets wrong results in transient condition.
This commit changes the grep filter rule to increase the robustness of
the result.

Closes-Bug: #1839910

commit_message:
Fix malformed InfluxDB query (LIMIT and OFFSET inverted)

In the method `InfluxClient::retrieve`, `LIMIT` and `OFFSET`
are inverted causing the query to systemically fail when
pagination is asked.

In InfluxQL, it seems that `LIMIT` must be before `OFFSET`.

More tests have been added to ensure that the correct format
is used inside the problematic method.

Change-Id: Iec11b83ade6d8441ce5ece1f3d3d9f73206fd9e4

commit_message:
Add digestmod when using hmac

Until Python 3.8 hmc.new() defaulted the digestmod argument to 'hmac-md5'.
This was deperecated, to be removed in Python 3.8 [1], so let's get
ready for new python.

Also switching to more secure sha1 algorithm, using md5 anywhere may
trigger alerts from automatic security tools.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/hmac.html

Change-Id: I4b365cb05de98bdd498b3c2094e4a77ab3944b12

commit_message:
Add undercloud-key-file and ssh_network options.

To enable the execution via ssh into the Undercloud node it's
required to pass also the ansible_ssh_user private key. This
options is part of the tripleo_common inventory.py, but defaults
to None.
This patch allows to pass this parameter in case it's needed.

Also, this patch allows to pass a different value for the host_network
parameter in TripleoInventory instantiation. Setting it by default to
ctlplane.

Change-Id: Id303f356c1b06906aa5aae43b0032bb80a712508

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-30 09:25:10.000000000', 'message': "Provide a proper way to choose VF in CNI

This commit fixes incorrect way for choosing VF in
SR-IOV binding driver.

Previously sriov-device-plugin has choosen device
by it's own way while CNI choosed first available VF.
This entities did not know anything about each other's
choice.

Now SR-IOV binding driver gets a list of used by
kubelet devices with help of Pod Resources Client, then
chooses device from this list which is not used by pod
yet and passes an appropriate VF into container's
network namespace.

Change-Id: I5b24981f715966369b05b8ab157f8bfe02afc2d4
Closes-Bug: 1826865
Signed-off-by: Danil Golov <d.golov@samsung.com>

chooses device from this list which is not used by pod
yet and passes an appropriate VF into container's
network namespace.

Also this commit contains tools for cluster upgrade.

Change-Id: I5b24981f715966369b05b8ab157f8bfe02afc2d4
Closes-Bug: 1826865
Signed-off-by: Danil Golov <d.golov@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Provide a proper way to choose VF in CNI

This commit fixes incorrect way for choosing VF in
SR-IOV binding driver.

Previously sriov-device-plugin has choosen device
by it's own way while CNI choosed first available VF.
This entities did not know anything about each other's
choice.

Now SR-IOV binding driver gets a list of used by
kubelet devices with help of Pod Resources Client, then
chooses device from this list which is not used by pod
yet and passes an appropriate VF into container's
network namespace.

Also this commit contains tools for cluster upgrade.

Change-Id: I5b24981f715966369b05b8ab157f8bfe02afc2d4
Closes-Bug: 1826865
Signed-off-by: Danil Golov <d.golov@samsung.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-22 02:07:22.000000000', 'message': 'runner/discover_container_name: force ps --sync when podman

Running "podman ps --sync (...)" is expensive but it is needed to
avoid race conditions when the containers are started.
This flag forces a sync of Podman's state against the OCI
runtime, resolving some state desync errors

Closes-Bug: #1839559
Change-Id: If4d8c268218bf83abed877a699fc583fb55ccbed
'}, {'created': '2019-08-22 04:00:56.000000000', 'message': 'WIP - runner/discover_container_name: drop -a and force -sync for podman ps

Running "podman ps --sync (...)" is expensive but it is needed to
avoid race conditions when the containers are started.
This flag forces a sync of Podman's state against the OCI
runtime, resolving some state desync errors.

Also, removing the -a to only list the running containers.

Closes-Bug: #1839559
Change-Id: If4d8c268218bf83abed877a699fc583fb55ccbed
'}, {'created': '2019-08-22 14:40:13.000000000', 'message': 'WIP - introduce container_running() and use it before running podman exec

container_running is a new method which will allow to return True if a
container is detected as running or False if not running.
There is a retry mechanism which if "podman ps" is used, will add "--sync" to
the command so we synchronize the state of OCI runtime.

It will be first used by the builder when a container is configured to
run "podman exec"; we'll first verify that the container exist otherwise
return an error.

TODO:
- add systemd support
- figure out if we need a sleep in the while between each iterations (in ms)

Co-Authored-By: Cédric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1839559
Change-Id: If4d8c268218bf83abed877a699fc583fb55ccbed

'}, {'created': '2019-08-25 15:39:01.000000000', 'message': 'Check if container is running before doing an exec

container_running is a new method which will allow to return True if a
container is detected as running or False if not running.
There is a retry mechanism which if "podman ps" is used, will add "--sync" to
the command so we synchronize the state of OCI runtime. Before doing a
"podman ps", we try to check if the service is running in systemd.
There is a very short sleep between the retries to give a chance to
podman to find the container if it takes a bit of time to start or seen
as started.

It will be used by the builder when a container is configured to
run "podman exec"; we'll first verify that the container exist otherwise
return an error and stop the deployment.

commit_message:
Check if container is running before doing an exec

container_running is a new method which will allow to return True if a
container is detected as running or False if not running.
There is a retry mechanism which if "podman ps" is used, will add "--sync" to
the command so we synchronize the state of OCI runtime. Before doing a
"podman ps", we try to check if the service is running in systemd.
There is a very short sleep between the retries to give a chance to
podman to find the container if it takes a bit of time to start or seen
as started.

It will be used by the builder when a container is configured to
run "podman exec"; we'll first verify that the container exist otherwise
return an error and stop the deployment.

This patch is mainly a workaround against a race condition where in
heavy-loaded environments, an exec can be run too early in a step where
the container is still starting.

It also consolidate the discover_container_name method in order to get
more chance to actually get a name.

Co-Authored-By: Cédric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1839559
Change-Id: If4d8c268218bf83abed877a699fc583fb55ccbed

commit_message:
Do not wait for console being started on timeout

Current logic tries to call communicate on Popen object when
starting shellinabox console even if console.subprocess_timeout
is hit. This blocks until the command is finished, with timeout
having no effect on it. It means that node lock is not released
until communicate call finishes.

Story: 2006429
Task: 36333
Change-Id: Ic7b878cd432990218a3d87047905ce0828b8da2a

Some projects (like Neutron) do import eventlet in docs/source/conf.py
. eventlet patches the subprocess module and due to that, the
submodule.CalledProcessError exception is not catched. So building the
documentation from an sdist tarball without having git installed (this
combination is common in package build envs) fails with:

commit_message:
Catch any exception when trying to call "git"

Some projects (like Neutron) do import eventlet in docs/source/conf.py
. eventlet patches the subprocess module and due to that, the
submodule.CalledProcessError exception is not caught. So building the
documentation from an sdist tarball with having git installed (this
combination is common in package build envs like RDO) fails with:

subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['git', 'log', '-n1', \
  '--format=%ad', [...snipped...]

Change-Id: Ibff93605996855f01ba2bbe793285674b5c71d2e

[{'created': '2019-08-23 16:45:03.000000000', 'message': "Fix trailing slashes for container locations

docker.io doesn't like urls that container double slashes which can lead
to incorrect auth problems. We should ensure that we are not

Closes-Bug: #1841203
"}]
commit_message:
Fix trailing slashes for container locations

docker.io doesn't like urls that container double slashes which can lead
to incorrect auth problems. We should ensure that we are not
constructing any urls with double slashes when processing uploads.

Change-Id: If8626b7f0828e5c108107854274257cd3e8d53eb
Closes-Bug: #1841203

commit_message:
Remove openSUSE 42.3 job

openSUSE 42.3 is dead, remove the job, we test with openSUSE 15 now (as
on master). This allows to remove the nodes from CI.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/677947
Change-Id: Ia4e98bd3b6368bcde02dc7376fa4441b8e577e12

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-10 10:56:55.000000000', 'message': 'Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare step to
work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in Stein it
will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

This way, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein to OVS and
in a post-upgrade step the upgrade from OVS to OVN would be performed.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-10 15:28:55.000000000', 'message': 'Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare step to
work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in Stein it
will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

This way, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein to OVS and
in a post-upgrade step the upgrade from OVS to OVN would be performed.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-11 06:33:51.000000000', 'message': 'Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare and converge
steps to work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in
Stein it will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

This way, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein with OVS and
if required, a post-upgrade step to upgrade from OVS to OVN would be
performed.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-11 10:10:34.000000000', 'message': 'Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare and converge
steps to work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in
Stein it will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

Also, the containers-prepare-parameter.yaml is shared between the UC
and the OC upgrade. For the case of the UC, there is no possibility to
deploy with ovn, so we force the neutron_driver option (defaulted to ovn
when creating the default containers-prepare-parameter.yaml file) to
openvswitch. However, for the OC, we need to identify if it was deployed
with the OVN service enabled and if so, set the netron_driver to ovn instead.

In summary, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein with OVS and
if required, a post-upgrade step to upgrade from OVS to OVN would be
performed. In the case the Rocky deployment was with OVN enabled we
perform a Rocky with OVN to Stein with OVN upgrade.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0
'}, {'created': '2019-07-11 13:18:59.000000000', 'message': 'Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare and converge
steps to work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in
Stein it will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

Also, the containers-prepare-parameter.yaml is shared between the UC
and the OC upgrade. For the case of the UC, there is no possibility to
deploy with ovn, so we force the neutron_driver option (defaulted to ovn
when creating the default containers-prepare-parameter.yaml file) to
openvswitch. However, for the OC, we need to identify if it was deployed
with the OVN service enabled and if so, set the netron_driver to ovn instead.

In summary, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein with OVS and
if required, a post-upgrade step to upgrade from OVS to OVN would be
performed. In the case the Rocky deployment was with OVN enabled we
perform a Rocky with OVN to Stein with OVN upgrade.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0

commit_message:
Pass neutron-ovs.yaml environment in upgrade prepare.

If the environmet is deployed in Rocky with OVS then we need to pass
the neutron-ovs.yml environment file for the upgrade prepare and converge
steps to work. Otherwise, as OVN is the Neutron engine by default in
Stein it will try to deploy with OVN and the upgrade will fail.

Also, the containers-prepare-parameter.yaml is shared between the UC
and the OC upgrade. For the case of the UC, there is no possibility to
deploy with ovn, so we force the neutron_driver option (defaulted to ovn
when creating the default containers-prepare-parameter.yaml file) to
openvswitch. However, for the OC, we need to identify if it was deployed
with the OVN service enabled and if so, set the netron_driver to ovn instead.

In summary, we first upgrade from Rocky with OVS to Stein with OVS and
if required, a post-upgrade step to upgrade from OVS to OVN would be
performed. In the case the Rocky deployment was with OVN enabled we
perform a Rocky with OVN to Stein with OVN upgrade.

Change-Id: I21bbf9cda977a1c269e2c1caad4bf88d3f6173b0

commit_message:
docs: ceph-ansible usage, add note around ceph keys

ceph-ansible by default generates what we call nova.keyring as
openstack.keyring - adding a note to not confuse users.

Change-Id: I3992a037ab8e7947e35521b5c721a89bd954fdcd

commit_message:
Remove unused project_ids in test_list_projects

This is to remove unused project_ids in test_list_projects,
also to change some unnecessary instance variables to local
variables, and also to use cls.__name__ in rand_name.

Change-Id: I4ef0b16db0869597e09e62d1694dbbb13013271b

commit_message:
Use galaxy_tags instead of categories

Ansible moved to use galaxy_tags instead of categories in
meta. We didn't update our meta, and we should do this.

Without this patch, ansible-lint with default rules would fail
due to rule 702 [1].

[1]: https://github.com/ansible/ansible-lint/blob/07b5194b44f6979480f57b96ea3d196fb59c0e7c/lib/ansiblelint/rules/MetaTagValidRule.py

Change-Id: Ide15cb25e85a70f1deabd465e623b22bd963b375

commit_message:
Install mariadb instead of mysql on deb distros

Debian 'buster' does not ship MySQL - only MariaDB is provided.
All supported platforms provide MariaDB.
This patch replaces MySQL with MariaDB to fix Debian Buster.

Debian Jessie is omitted on purpose - no need to touch
unsupported releases.

Change-Id: I9084f70dee2e1ee6eb1f4933ae0f9ef8809c1adc
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Marcin Juszkiewicz <marcin.juszkiewicz@linaro.org>
Co-authored-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2019-07-10 07:12:33.000000000', 'message': "Create lbaas driver instance only when it's needed

_drv_lbaas is used only in _update_services which are under
_is_network_policy_enabled. Creating lbaas drv instance in
case when it was omitted in enabled_handlers could lead to
undesired behaviour, such as exception.

Change-Id: Iacb4c4765f9b6b507ea65b948f18ac935151bb31
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Create lbaas driver instance only when it's needed

_drv_lbaas is used only in _update_services which are under
_is_network_policy_enabled. Creating lbaas drv instance in
case when it was omitted in enabled_handlers could lead to
undesired behaviour, such as exception.

Change-Id: Iacb4c4765f9b6b507ea65b948f18ac935151bb31
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Moves monasca-thresh java.io.tmpdir to existing docker volume

This prevents the container's root filesystem from filling up.

Change-Id: Icc5a08c82312d6688edf2ef36562967ac94e8ac9
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/674779
Closes-Bug: #1839149

subject: Constrain the size of Docker logs
messages: [{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-08-27 14:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-08-27 15:08:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nThanks Pierre'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-08-28 06:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-28 08:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-27 14:44:08.000000000', 'message': 'Constrain the size of Docker logs

Even though Kolla services are configured to log output to file rather than
stdout, some stdout still occurs when for example the container re(starts).
Since the Docker logs are not constrained in size, they can fill up the
docker volumes drive and bring down the host. One example of when this is
particularly problematic is when Fluentd cannot parse a log message. The
warning output is written to the Docker log and in production we have seen
it eat 100GB of disk space in less than a day. We could configure Fluentd
not to do this, but the problem may still occur via another mechanism.

Change-Id: Ia6d3935263a5909c71750b34eb69e72e6e558b7a
Closes-Bug: #1794249
(cherry picked from commit bd54b99132d019b747dcd98af9371628625c8a1b)
'}]
commit_message:
Constrain the size of Docker logs

Even though Kolla services are configured to log output to file rather than
stdout, some stdout still occurs when for example the container re(starts).
Since the Docker logs are not constrained in size, they can fill up the
docker volumes drive and bring down the host. One example of when this is
particularly problematic is when Fluentd cannot parse a log message. The
warning output is written to the Docker log and in production we have seen
it eat 100GB of disk space in less than a day. We could configure Fluentd
not to do this, but the problem may still occur via another mechanism.

Change-Id: Ia6d3935263a5909c71750b34eb69e72e6e558b7a
Closes-Bug: #1794249
(cherry picked from commit bd54b99132d019b747dcd98af9371628625c8a1b)

commit_message:
Add support for using custom Logstash patterns

A user may want to define and use Logstash patterns. This
commit adds support to copy them into the Monasca Log
Transformer container. In the future support could be
added for other Logstash containers.

Change-Id: Id8cde14af6dc7f49714f6b1cb878882d0048d293

commit_message:
Support configuration of trusted CA certificate file

This commit adds the functionality for an operator to specify
their own trusted CA certificate file for interacting with the
Keystone API.

Implements: blueprint support-trusted-ca-certificate-file
Change-Id: I84f9897cc8e107658701fb309ec318c0f805883b

commit_message:
py3: fix up listings on sharded containers

We were playing a little fast & loose with types before; as a result,
marker/end_marker weren't quite working right. In particular, we were
checking whether a WSGI string was contained in a shard range, while
ShardRange assumes all comparisons are against native strings.

Now, get everything to native strings before making comparisons, and
get them back to wsgi when we shove them in the params dict.

Change-Id: Iddf9e089ef95dc709ab76dc58952a776246991fd

commit_message:
config: disable notifications by default

We are currently pushing out notifications even if Ceilometer is
not enabled resulting in huge queues.  Let's not do that.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/678308
Change-Id: I0f8f5e3beaf9eca9127f1a37ffa93e0a5dac2974
(cherry picked from commit edde66b9a0dae24a9288da240455890c2f100282)

commit_message:
Set EnablePackageInstall to true by default for in-place OS upgrade

For in-place upgrades via Leapp, which is the default, we are
dependent on package installs. User can still override the default
value if they wish so, but they might have to pull in the content by
some manual means.

Change-Id: I5e5629d2baed97988bc65151d51c115a2a263dfc
Partial-Bug: #1831690

commit_message:
Parametrize UpgradeLeappDevelSkip to pass multiple env variables.

One of the ways Leapp has to skip some checks is by
passing some environment files when to the leapp
execution environment. Up to now we only tested the
LEAPP_DEVEL_SKIP_RHSM=1 one, however there are many
more. So it makes sense to parametrize this variable
to allow passing a string with all the environment
variables we want to pass to Leapp.

Change-Id: Ic9f4a36cef25150708a71396bea754a93f87661d
(cherry picked from commit 56ba9e90db3800935997f37e805a1b742b524769)

subject: Data context is always empty in a log
messages:
[{'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2018-07-29 22:34:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2018-07-30 07:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-07-30 07:56:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2018-07-30 08:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-30 09:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-30 09:25:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, I think I understood what this patch aims to address but it does it very roughly. To me it looks more like a hack than a proper solution.

There's already a couple of tickets for that:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/mistral/+bug/1337268
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/mistral/+spec/mistral-secure-sensitive-data

There's been a number of ideas how to approach this fundamental problem. I believe we can't afford hacky solutions for this. Yes, this patch can close one particular security hole but for a certain price (debuggability of workflows), but there's a ton of other places where a potentially sensitive information will be leaking.

I'd really recommend to get back to the spec where we discussed that and consider the problem more widely."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-08-28 06:34:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

No changes for too long.'}]

commit_message:
Data context is always empty in a log

* Override __str__ and __repr__ methods for DataFlow class.
* Don't publish a data context as a task result.
  Because it's insecure and it can be cut by
  "execution_field_size_limit_kb" for a big workflow.
* Rename data to context in a logs

Change-Id: Ifebcb286e12aa3a170806c45e45bf70ec1a64ec1
Signed-off-by: Vitalii Solodilov <mcdkr@yandex.ru>
Closes-Bug: #1784247

commit_message:
Allow the execution of leapp without RHSM subscription.

There are a set of workarounds which can be executed in order
skip the RHSM subscription requirement to run the Leapp tool. This
patch includes an option leapp_unsubscribed, a boolean, that when
setted to true enables an environment variable LEAPP_DEVEL_SKIP_RHSM
which skips the subscription check.

Change-Id: Ifca276dabad3c87f86681704d4fad0658c66f4b2

commit_message:
neutron: Fix "Provides" for neutron

- The base package shouldn't be providing all the "-agent" dependencies
since every agent is a separate subpackage.
- Have the l2-agents provide "openstack-neutron-l2-agent". This is e.g.
use by some tools in (openSUSE)

Change-Id: I6b808970245a90dd372721ee673e2a6fc8d5882d

commit_message:
Identify Cinder as the Block Storage Service

According to openstack/governance/projects.yaml, Cinder is the
OpenStack Block Storage service.  This patch changes the file
used to generate the specs.openstack.org index page and RSS feed
page to identify Cinder properly.  The change is only to displayed
text, URLs are not modified by this commit.

Change-Id: I2730dd82f1b6dd329a36e73150fec9c36470fc17
Partial-bug: #1841645

commit_message:
Fix: Restore output 'VolumeBackupsRestore' object is not iterable

VolumeBackupsRetore object has '_info' attribute
which contains the output data of the restore
command which should be returned instead of the
'VolumeBackupsRestore' object.

Change-Id: I64b75649c1ac9c24e05a197f7280975564b4d386
Story: 2004740
Task: 28811
(cherry picked from commit 24255ad0dde608a19d371a27c13714098097f185)

subject: Add retries when loading keystone data and fetching endpoints
messages: [{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-24 08:42:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-26 09:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-28 02:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-24 08:42:41.000000000', 'message': 'Add retries when loading keystone data and fetching endpoints

We may end up loading lots of nested stacks concurrently with
convergence and those would try to discover endpoints and fetch
access info objects from keystone. This at times results in
ConnectTimeout errors from keystone. We can avoid these errors
by adding some retries.

Also adds retries to client_plugin get_endpoint() calls, which has
simillar issue.

Change-Id: I18cde971248eff5783f97c9e7a60316d7dd93431
Task: 36349
(cherry picked from commit 6fb8ac250ae27810516b89f273923d6b786606b5)
'}]
commit_message:
Add retries when loading keystone data and fetching endpoints

We may end up loading lots of nested stacks concurrently with
convergence and those would try to discover endpoints and fetch
access info objects from keystone. This at times results in
ConnectTimeout errors from keystone. We can avoid these errors
by adding some retries.

Also adds retries to client_plugin get_endpoint() calls, which has
simillar issue.

Change-Id: I18cde971248eff5783f97c9e7a60316d7dd93431
Task: 36349
(cherry picked from commit 6fb8ac250ae27810516b89f273923d6b786606b5)

commit_message:
Add volume-type during database mechanism

We will hit an error without specific volume type, more logs in
following:

`ERROR: Validation error: instance['volume']['type'] None is not of type 'string' (HTTP 400)`

This patch will be fixing this issue and add more detail instruction.

Change-Id: I037d99a0e0e171c853cb91d6c6e632e7a09479ee

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-23 21:08:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing test branch for nova-lxd

This has been missing previously and the master branch of nova-lxd
will have been used mistakenly in tests up to now. As nova-lxd is now
deprecated and the master branch empty, tests on OSA stable branches
fail.

This patch ensures that an appropriate stable branch version of nova-lxd
is used.

Change-Id: Ieaedbe6990bf709c1fa89c4d3f4a8b5ae7080851
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing test branch for nova-lxd

This has been missing previously and the master branch of nova-lxd
will have been used mistakenly in tests up to now. As nova-lxd is now
deprecated and the master branch empty, tests on OSA stable branches
fail.

This patch ensures that an appropriate stable branch version of nova-lxd
is used.

Change-Id: Ieaedbe6990bf709c1fa89c4d3f4a8b5ae7080851

commit_message:
Add NeutronPermittedEthertypes on OVS agent

Adds support for configuring additional ethernet types in neutron
security groups. See https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668224 for related
neutron change.

Related-Bug: #1832758

Depends-On: I9ed539745a705936d9a5110a9cfb05c2f28b0bbb
Change-Id: I692dee9343906f2103fc6cf9f9f5944b81dbe8ec

subject: Fix networking-baremetal CI
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 16688, 'name': 'Rodolfo Alonso', 'email': 'ralonsoh@redhat.com', 'username': 'rodolfo-alonso-hernandez'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jensås', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}, {'_account_id': 24828, 'name': 'Kaifeng Wang', 'email': 'kaifeng.w@gmail.com', 'username': 'wangkf'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-09 21:09:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-12 13:28:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-12 19:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-15 10:02:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I belive I have reproduced this issue locally.

When I run the test: ironic_tempest_plugin.tests.scenario.test_baremetal_basic_ops.BaremetalBasicOps.test_baremetal_server_ops the instance is deployed, it boots and it get's IP address 10.1.0.7.

I can ping and ssh the host on that IP:
$ ping 10.1.0.7 -c 1
PING 10.1.0.7 (10.1.0.7) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from 10.1.0.7: icmp_seq=1 ttl=55 time=313 ms

$\xa0nc 10.1.0.7 22
SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4


There is also a floaing IP associated which I cannot ping or SSH to.

stack@ironic-devstack:~$ openstack floating ip list
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------------------------------+
| ID                                   | Floating IP Address | Fixed IP Address | Port                                 | Floating Network                     | Project                          |
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------------------------------+
| 92e65aad-4c57-4bf7-b0a9-9ba59412c46a | 172.24.5.37         | 10.1.0.7         | 4ae4ae48-56d4-42a2-8d29-f01939d4d635 | 9bdf2339-cf6a-4660-bef1-f56fda3a4361 | 0958369c1dd541838c483ab13d458588 |
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+----------------------------------+

stack@ironic-devstack:~$ ping 172.24.5.37
PING 172.24.5.37 (172.24.5.37) 56(84) bytes of data.
From 172.24.5.1 icmp_seq=1 Destination Host Unreachable

stack@ironic-devstack:~$ nc 172.24.5.37 22
stack@ironic-devstack:~$ echo $?
1


The tempest tests create tenant networks, and use the public-network/public-subnet for the floating IP, non of these networks have subnets with segment association. The provisioning network used for provisioning and cleaning does have segment association which require the networking-baremetal ml2 mech driver + agent dance to work for the routed network.

Since both provisioning and cleaning is working, my conclusion is that the networking-baremetal components are actually working.

The issue here is that the floating ip address is not working.


I will keep investigating."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-15 10:20:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I belive I have reproduced this issue locally.
 > 
 > When I run the test: ironic_tempest_plugin.tests.scenario.test_baremetal_basic_ops.BaremetalBasicOps.test_baremetal_server_ops
 > the instance is deployed, it boots and it get's IP address
 > 10.1.0.7.
 > 
 > I can ping and ssh the host on that IP:
 > $ ping 10.1.0.7 -c 1
 > PING 10.1.0.7 (10.1.0.7) 56(84) bytes of data.
 > 64 bytes from 10.1.0.7: icmp_seq=1 ttl=55 time=313 ms
 > 
 > $\xa0nc 10.1.0.7 22
 > SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4
 > 

yarn, the above is not correct. I cannot ping that address, turns out the 10.1.0.0 network is used internally and I got the reply from some host on the corporate network. After switching off the VPN it turns out I cannot ping the node."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-15 15:26:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Since both provisioning and cleaning is working, my conclusion is
 > that the networking-baremetal components are actually working.
 > 
 > The issue here is that the floating ip address is not working.
 > 
 > 
 > I will keep investigating.

What if we drop the connection to the FIP? It is not valid in the v6 world....'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-16 11:41:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > Since both provisioning and cleaning is working, my conclusion is
 > > that the networking-baremetal components are actually working.
 > >
 > > The issue here is that the floating ip address is not working.
 > >
 > >
 > > I will keep investigating.
 > 
 > What if we drop the connection to the FIP? It is not valid in the
 > v6 world....

I think we need the FIP to verify connectivity to the instance? (Note that my initial report that I could ping/ssh the VM was invalid. I ended up getting a resonse from an corporate lab system due to the VPN connection.)


I've noticed that the PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY="172.24.5.1" is on the br-ex interface. In OVS there are no patch to br-int on br-ex. And after stacking I cannot ping the IP of the public port on router1 which is in the public network. On a "vanilla" devstack setup pinging router1's interface on the public netwok works, and there is a patch beetween br-ex and br-int. I've been trying to change things bridge mappings, setting PUBLIC_BRIDGE="brbm" to move the PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY from br-ex to brbm but so far I have'nt figured out how to get things wired up so that the PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY interface can reach ports on the public network.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-16 12:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > > Since both provisioning and cleaning is working, my conclusion
 > is
 > > > that the networking-baremetal components are actually working.
 > > >
 > > > The issue here is that the floating ip address is not working.
 > > >
 > > >
 > > > I will keep investigating.
 > >
 > > What if we drop the connection to the FIP? It is not valid in the
 > > v6 world....
 > 
 > I think we need the FIP to verify connectivity to the instance?
 > (Note that my initial report that I could ping/ssh the VM was
 > invalid. I ended up getting a resonse from an corporate lab system
 > due to the VPN connection.)
 > 
 > 
 > I've noticed that the PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY="172.24.5.1" is on the
 > br-ex interface. In OVS there are no patch to br-int on br-ex. And
 > after stacking I cannot ping the IP of the public port on router1
 > which is in the public network. On a "vanilla" devstack setup
 > pinging router1's interface on the public netwok works, and there
 > is a patch beetween br-ex and br-int. I've been trying to change
 > things bridge mappings, setting PUBLIC_BRIDGE="brbm" to move the
 > PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY from br-ex to brbm but so far I have'nt
 > figured out how to get things wired up so that the
 > PUBLIC_NETWORK_GATEWAY interface can reach ports on the public
 > network.

Commenting Q_USE_PROVIDERNET_FOR_PUBLIC and adding OVS_BRIDGE_MAPPINGS may be what we are looking for. BaremetalBasicOps.test_baremetal_server_ops is passing with below change in my local reproducer. I will update push an update to this patch.

  # Q_USE_PROVIDERNET_FOR_PUBLIC="False"
  OVS_BRIDGE_MAPPINGS=mynetwork:brbm,public:br-ex'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-16 12:41:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-08-16 13:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-19 13:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-20 00:36:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-08-20 10:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-09 21:09:55.000000000', 'message': "Remove vif_details check

Vif_details has evolved in neutron and now some
additional information is now returned. It seems
to make the most sense, to just not try and validate
it's contents in networking-baremetal since this
mech driver is just a pass-through to reconcile
information with the baremetal use case.

Change-Id: I4ae6eb6345ff45b91f63f1687d1c640f9bf25e54
Related-Bug: 1821058
"}, {'created': '2019-08-12 13:28:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix networking-baremetal CI

Vif_details has evolved in neutron and now some
additional information is now returned. It seems
to make the most sense, to just not try and validate
it's contents in networking-baremetal since this
mech driver is just a pass-through to reconcile
information with the baremetal use case.

Additionally, devstack changes have resulted in
our authentication configuration setup being
incorrect. This patch calls the correct method.

Change-Id: I4ae6eb6345ff45b91f63f1687d1c640f9bf25e54
Related-Bug: 1821058
"}, {'created': '2019-08-12 19:00:45.000000000', 'message': "Fix networking-baremetal CI

to make the most sense, to just not try and validate

Additionally, devstack changes have resulted in
our authentication configuration setup being
incorrect. This patch calls the correct method.

Also bump the number of test VMs to 4, as more tests
have been added and slightly greater concurrency is
required.

Change-Id: I4ae6eb6345ff45b91f63f1687d1c640f9bf25e54
Related-Bug: 1821058

to make the most sense, to just not try and validate
it's contents in networking-baremetal since this
mech driver is just a pass-through to reconcile
information with the baremetal use case.

Change the devstack job to use a provider network for
the public network and set bridge mapping for the
public network to fix tempest jobs that fail to
connect to instances via floating IP.

Additionally, devstack changes have resulted in
our authentication configuration setup being
incorrect. This patch calls the correct method.

Also bump the number of test VMs to 4, as more tests
have been added and slightly greater concurrency is
required.

commit_message:
Fix networking-baremetal CI

Force the use of the legacy neutron devstack plugin.

Change the devstack job to use a provider network for
the public network and set bridge mapping for the
public network to fix tempest jobs that fail to
connect to instances via floating IP.

Additionally, devstack changes have resulted in
our authentication configuration setup being
incorrect. This patch calls the correct method.

Also bump the number of test VMs to 4, as more tests
have been added and slightly greater concurrency is
required.

And disable cleaning to save time in CI. While cleaning
is a separate network and series of attach/detaches for
for the underlying ports, we already perform the same
actions with deployment.

Change-Id: I4ae6eb6345ff45b91f63f1687d1c640f9bf25e54
Related-Bug: 1821058

[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-06-24 13:01:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-08-09 18:11:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck # test output is gone'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-09 21:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there an equivalent patch for Cyborg itself?

This code is mostly outdated and some community members are planning to update it. It may not be productive to fix old code for Py3.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-08-12 14:32:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Sundar, there isn't a patch for cyborg. The reason why is because it didn't already have py3 zuul testing so it wasn't a candidate to upgrade to py3-train zuul testing."}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:43:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Sundar, there isn't a patch for cyborg. The reason why is because
 > it didn't already have py3 zuul testing so it wasn't a candidate to
 > upgrade to py3-train zuul testing.

@Corey, isn't Py3 testing one of the Train goals? Is there any consequence to not supporting it?

For the cyborg client, it still uses v1 API of Cyborg, whereas we are moving to v2 in Train. We haven't had enough contributor time to focus on the client in this cycle. Fixing Py3 issues in outdated code is not productive."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-12 17:07:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Corey, isn't Py3 testing one of the Train goals?

No, it was one of the Pike goals.

> Is there any consequence to not supporting it?

> For the cyborg client, it still uses v1 API of Cyborg, whereas we are moving to v2 in Train. We haven't had enough contributor time to focus on the client in this cycle. Fixing Py3 issues in outdated code is not productive.

Most distros where clients run already have python3.7 as the default, so we really should be testing it on py37. FWIW the issues blocking the gate here are probably trivial to fix."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-23 17:12:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-23 18:48:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30759, 'date': '2019-08-27 06:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-28 02:44:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-08-28 02:44:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Ensure Barbican required roles are created by Keystone

Presently there are several roles: audit, observer, and key-manger:
service-admin that are used in Barbican policy but not generated
by Keystone during a TripleO Deployment.

This change updates Keystone's manifest to include creation of these
missing roles then the Barbican API is included as part of a depl-
oyment.

Change-Id: I6d5d0a37abeb54600bb70e22fabde9479320ab81
(cherry picked from commit 970462b56257bccc7671dfc770b3301eaf3acb58)
(cherry picked from commit 555498ba8c8edebc523b57b766738229abc8d16a)
(cherry picked from commit d391ddf6a82341eb40fbfce21f1782ee68ef0e17)

commit_message:
Move centos 7 buildah jobs to non-voting

These jobs are failing sporadically.
Noting that we now have rhel-8 jobs for buildah
and the buildah version on centos is older,
this review moves these jobs to non-voting.

Change-Id: I6e14db844ea50e0efe81555063bb054c0d8fa324
Related-Bug: #1840849

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-swift-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/0e96cec/ : SUCCESS in 2m 10s
- gate-swift-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-python27-ubuntu-xenial/44be76a/ : SUCCESS in 3m 12s
- gate-swift-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-python34/5693f74/ : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- gate-swift-python35-nv http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-python35-nv/d34fcaf/ : SUCCESS in 1m 10s (non-voting)
- gate-swift-tox-func-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-ubuntu-xenial/734c46c/ : SUCCESS in 3m 36s
- gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-fast-post-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-fast-post-ubuntu-xenial/cbfb5fe/ : SUCCESS in 3m 36s
- gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-encryption-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func-in-process-encryption-ubuntu-xenial/237e434/ : SUCCESS in 3m 12s
- gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial/bfce2d4/ : SUCCESS in 39m 12s
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-ubuntu-xenial-nv/4c1a130/ : SUCCESS in 43m 23s (non-voting)
- gate-grenade-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-grenade-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial/a90a70d/ : SUCCESS in 25m 02s
- gate-swift-dsvm-functional-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional-ubuntu-xenial/d63b7ae/ : SUCCESS in 16m 44s
- gate-swift-tox-bandit-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-tox-bandit-ubuntu-xenial/3186e6b/ : SUCCESS in 1m 14s (non-voting)
- gate-swift-dsvm-functional-identity-v3-only-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/05/391605/1/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional-identity-v3-only-ubuntu-xenial-nv/fbdeb7e/ : SUCCESS in 16m 09s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-10-31 22:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I can see what you're going for, but i'm not sure a recon stat at the end of the cycle is the best place to be adding new stuff like this

mainly - it's super niche - it's a fairly specific thing to track/monitor

plus a similar metric/value/ey could be applied to ssync if we gave it a better name

plus we already know that sometimes we're going to rsync suffixes even tho their contents are the same if there's a race from when we calculate local and remote hashes

... and even if we thought it was higher than we like (let's assume it is!) it's not any more clear what'd we do to change it - or especially what you might do in a running system if you noticed it trending upwards (is that even a big problem compared to other things we might monitor/optimize?)

and then lastly you can probably pull this information ad-hoc from the logs by using the fact that the successful rsync log message goes to debug log level if there is no data transferred (existing code uses the same "if not results" logic)

Another option would perhaps be that in addition to logging to DEBUG we change the message slightly to indicate the useless work.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-11-01 17:32:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I also wanted to say I was functionally testing this by forcing the REPLICATE verbs to always return mis-matched hashes from the object-server

    diff --git a/swift/obj/server.py b/swift/obj/server.py
    index 408b641..5cc6cc3 100644
    --- a/swift/obj/server.py
    +++ b/swift/obj/server.py
    @@ -1076,6 +1076,7 @@ class ObjectController(BaseStorageServer):
             except DiskFileDeviceUnavailable:
                 resp = HTTPInsufficientStorage(drive=device, request=request)
             else:
    +            hashes = {k: 'monkies' for k in hashes}
                 resp = Response(body=pickle.dumps(hashes))
             return resp"}, {'account_id': 16896, 'date': '2016-11-24 11:43:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

>I can see what you're going for, but i'm not sure a recon stat at the end of the cycle is the best place to be adding new stuff like this

this metrics is almost same as "hashmash", so same place is fine for me.

> plus a similar metric/value/ey could be applied to ssync if we gave it a better name

i tried to figure out place to put this, and i'm not sure if it's possible

> plus we already know that sometimes we're going to rsync suffixes even tho their contents are the same if there's a race from when we calculate local and remote hashes

yep, but metrics can say if "sometimes" is not "too often" after any change/upgrade/fix/... Change of this metric can indicate something bad just happens (and it really happens, see next)

> ... and even if we thought it was higher than we like (let's assume it is!) it's not any more clear what'd we do to change it - or especially what you might do in a running system if you noticed it trending upwards (is that even a big problem compared to other things we might monitor/optimize?)

yep. But thanks to this patch, we found this bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1634967
This metric can say where in Swift code is bug. But it can say: Hey, Ops, you done something, and something happens. Look into it. Same way is working all others metrics for us (hashmatch, failed, ...)

So it's really usefull.

> and then lastly you can probably pull this information ad-hoc from the logs by using the fact that the successful rsync log message goes to debug log level if there is no data transferred (existing code uses the same "if not results" logic)

which is much more work. Just have "number to read from recon" is much more simple for production (for us)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-12-01 10:28:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

maybe we could put this on the agenda to discuss at the next swift meeting

as a developer - I'm fine with this change - it's small and easy instrumentation that helped debug this particular issue this one time - great

as a maintainer - I'm frustrated by a lack of direction around cluster telemetry - if this showed up in our recon drops one day - how would people know to update their tooling - or what the value means or what to do with it?

as an operator - I hate recon.  The drops are too slow and don't give me any insight into a cycle - or half of my nodes are showing stale data.  The cli is gross.  I already have a monitoring agent on my nodes - the loadavg/memory stuff seems like compleatly "not our domain" bullshit.  How do people monitor their distributed fleet - swift doesn't need to invent new stuff here; piggy back on what works.  We picked collectd for system metrics, because it has great plugin support for monitoring other applications we run (e.g. memcached [1]); so naturally for swift we have a collectd plugins to snarf the recon json directly - polling the recon stores via HTTP parsing the json to munge it into metrics and funnel it into time series data store seems wrose.  If we had good opensource collectd integration (or something else?) could we drop some of recon ecosystem - is there a more agnostic way to emit application specific stats like to write to /proc?  Half the stuff collected by recon are counters - they are only sensible to consume as #'s per time unit (and cycle is a bad time unit!) - counters should get emitted as statsd metrics (they're better documented anyway [2])

So that's like 2 out of my 3 hats telling me this is good money at bad - but lacking a better plan maybe it's better to polish the turd than to live in the S^&*?

1. https://collectd.org/wiki/index.php/Table_of_Plugins
2. http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/admin_guide.html?highlight=telemetry#reporting-metrics-to-statsd'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2017-05-25 00:50:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm still +1 on this change - i haven't really looked that closely at the implementation - as long as it works and doesn't break anything I don't care.  If we had some infrastructure to document recon I'd probably say that should be updated - but we don't - so i'm not that inclined to say "you must create a plan for documenting recon metrics before this can merge" - rather i'm just less excited about adding another undocumented thing I have to figure out how to maintain/support/not-ever-break.

If we could get (or you wanted to kickstart) an organized effort behind making recon drops better/useful/documented I could *definitely* support that (+2s and +As abound time permitting) - dumping more rando junk in there I'm more meh +1, good luck!

... maybe romain could review?  He uses recon and might have some opinions/vision/design ideas that might help me get some context.  I think braincline was also at the summit talking about dumping more periodic stats (more frequently that cycle) into recon drops?  

... who else ... idk?  thiago is positive/helpful just *in general* - if you explain to him how this change being merged would directly contribute to an increase on your own personal overall happiness he might help you out!?

If you feel like the change is blocked there is always notmyname - the PTL will save us all!  Good luck!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-15 01:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 02:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 16896, 'date': '2019-08-24 19:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-27 16:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-27 16:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Just fixing up unit tests following https://review.opendev.org/#/c/555563/'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-27 21:37:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}]

commit_message:
Added rsync_no_change metrics to recon

This counter is incremented if rsync doesn't return any stdout. That means
rsync run was "useless", because it didn't sync any data. This happens
when there are suffix missmatched/desync but no data changes.

Change-Id: I3aa578d053a0397207fe0911a084bd47a34dd1f8

commit_message:
Prepare container images using tripleo ansible role

The THT file has been converted to use a newly created role found within
TripleO-Ansible. The THT process will now run all tasks through the role
using "include_role". To ensure we're keeping things separated, all of
the data transformations will still be taken care of in the heat template.
This ensures we have clean lines of separation allowing both services to
work as expected, without nuance or confusion.

Depends-On: Ic6e26eb95734ccf17e42e649b5e5808e1a096a78
Change-Id: I3a87dbb6e9fdaf78f6ffa2ac03a0069222c12d48
Story: 2005985
Task: 34442
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>

commit_message:
Use docker_container Ansible module

The docker Ansible module was removed in Ansible 2.4. It was replaced
by dedicated modules docker_container and docker_image.

This is valid for Rocky and Queens versions only. Stein and newer
versions use Podman.

Closes-Bug: #1840742
Change-Id: I9eafaa93e5e8e88e25e7958b7aba3a4d90de78ad

commit_message:
Use default value for NovaLiveMigrationWaitForVIFPlug

The support to set config paramter NovaLiveMigrationWaitForVIFPlug
was added in I0048d1f57eeb3418b52f225f87810ea1a7250a0f  which
default to true but has a condition as well, because of which
live-migration fails with timeout.

This changes removes the condition and uses the default value.

Also change Ib9fe6e1bfea1d5f62b2f2b6fdb12d16878108c3f fixes
the issue in networking-ovn project.

Change-Id: Iba2b7a94c23ff3bcc311e92b63d6c05d9cb6d065
(cherry picked from commit 82304701981c820c0b6eae7992ab8c36a8dbcd3f)

commit_message:
Add KOLLA_BOOTSTRAP=True to 2 bootstrap containers

keystone_bootstrap and mysql_sync_credentials are containers which need
to be run on the bootstrap node only, there is no need to run them on
other controllers. It avoids useless verbosity when they fail to
execute.

Change-Id: I4acf992e41f60a5462f8fa35964c051ca15895ba
Closes-Bug: #1840999

commit_message:
Adds LibvirtLogFilters to define a libvirtd filter

LibvirtLogFilters to select a different logging level for a given
category log outputs, as specified in https://libvirt.org/logging.html .
Default:

'1:libvirt 1:qemu 1:conf 1:security 3:event 3:json 3:file 3:object 1:util'

Conflicts:
      deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml

Removed the conflict, as this file is not present in Queens
release and corresponding changes are done in
puppet/services/nova-libvirt.yaml file.

Depends-On: Ic48afe856ae60654d6cebf627b12509881933c59
Change-Id: I85b09ddeb61b2f3563f81eb423e8f05b18fe984a
Closes-Bug: 1840140
(cherry picked from commit 71516f2816aa9705bbe74533957557269094fd32)
(cherry picked from commit 78d16ded1e06b872b1ebda1c0f67ceebf53b665a)
(cherry picked from commit beb1e8f67a098c7ed3912edbb6db4353abee675f)

commit_message:
Adds LibvirtLogFilters to define a libvirtd filter

LibvirtLogFilters to select a different logging level for a given
category log outputs, as specified in https://libvirt.org/logging.html .
Default:

'1:libvirt 1:qemu 1:conf 1:security 3:event 3:json 3:file 3:object 1:util'

Conflicts:
      deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml

Removed the conflict, as this file is not present in Rocky
release and corresponding changes are done in
puppet/services/nova-libvirt.yaml file.

Depends-On: Ic48afe856ae60654d6cebf627b12509881933c59
Change-Id: I85b09ddeb61b2f3563f81eb423e8f05b18fe984a
Closes-Bug: 1840140
